editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: WRITTEN By a Perſon of Honour.

q.p: Ficta, voluptatis cauſa, ſint proxima veris.

div.p: LONDON: Printed by J. Cottrel, for Samuel Speed, at the Rainbow neer the Inner Temple-gate in Fleetſtreet. 1664.

list.item: KING of Naples, Old and timorous, fears to be dethron'd by his Son.
AMINTOR, the Prince, His Son, Generous and Popular, yet full of reſpect and duty to the King, a Lover of Clariana.
VALERIO, a Count, In love with the Princeſs, and after General for the King.
TERRAEFILIUS, An unknown perſon, fancied by the Prince for his rare parts and qualities, and by him advanced to higheſt Dignities, call'd in Court Caliſto.
DUKE of Calabria, A Favourer of the Prince, and Father to Clariana.
FRANGYPANE, A Noble-Man, endu'd with Courage, and other brave qualities, which are deſtroy'd by the infection of Love and Poetry: He is in love with Livia.
MALIGNO, LUSSURIO, Two Sycophants that batten upon the Kings weakneſs, and great enemies to the Prince.
HORTENSIO, Lieutenant to Valerio, a worthy Gentleman.
JULIANA, The Princeſs, in love with Valerio.
CLARIANA, The Dukes Daughter, in love with the Prince.
LIVIA, A Lady attending the Princeſs, belov'd by Frangypane. Ladies.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.p: Enter a Drunkard, a Morice-dancer, a Buffoon, a Bawd, a Whore, and a She-Gypſie; they dance an Antick. Which done, Enter Tragedy in ſtate, in a Crimſon Robe held up by two Roman Gladiators, a Crown upon her head, a Scepter in one hand, and a Ponyard in the other; at whoſe entrance the Dancers all ſtart back.

lg.head: Tragedy.
lg.l: YOu ſeem amaz'd; pray let me wonder too:
I have more cauſe to ſtand amaz'd thin you,
To ſee your mimick faces uſher in
So deep a Tragedy. Thoſe that have ſeen
My Crimſon Viſage on the Stage before,
Expect deſignes both deep and dark: nay more,
Counſels of Kings diſclos'd: They look to ſee
Me uſher'd in with wonted Majeſty,
No light Morice. Sure the Author's frantick,
To preſent for a Prologue ſuch an Antick;
Or elſe he humours thoſe that are ſo: few
Can like things ſo extravagantly new,
I mean, that are judicious: ſome think fit
To number Dances in the rank of Wit.
Such may his entrance pleaſe; whilſt onely they
Of deeper judgement do applaud his Play.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: THou loveſt us, Terraefilius?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Love you, my Lord? What man dare queſtion it
That hath a life, or may be mortal? Would
I could finde a word apt to expreſs it,
And then ſome action to make good that word;
My love would throw me on the enterprize,
And baniſh by performance the leaſt doubt
Might bring my Love or Duty in ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Neither is doubted, Terraefilius;
I do believe, and cheriſh both.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Give't (my Lord) the name of Duty onely;
A Vaſſal's love unto his Prince is ſuch:
Or, if you pleaſe, of Gratitude, for all
Thoſe Favours, thoſe Seas of Princely Favours,
Your Bounty prodigally ſhower'd on me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I count them, Terraefilius, well beſtow'd:
When Princes meet with a clear faithful Breaſt,
One, who nor flatters nor betrays his truſt,
(As I have done in thee) they ought eſteem't
The richeſt Jewel in their Diadem.
When Hunting accidentally I found thee,
Clad in the roughneſs of a Souldiers Garb,
Then did I ſee Deſert ſhine through thy Rags,
A valiant look linkt to an honeſt heart;
And ſince, thy vertue hath made good all my
Predictions of thee.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your Grace doth ruine my ſmall ſtock of worth,
Quite bankrupt my hopes, which are by ſervice
To deſerve your favour. But Nature's poor
In but affording me a ſingle life,
Scarce valuable to looſe in your defence:
The ſum of all my riches is your love.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: In which Exchequer, thou ſhalt finde no waſte,
Nor ſtudy wanting to advance thy State:
For I deſigne Vertue a Triumph in▪
Thy Greatneſs; therefore, Terraefilius,
I will prefer thee to my Fathers love,
Endear thee to his heart: ſuch honeſt Souls
Should ſtill cohabit with a Monarchs ear.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your Grace doth ſeem to love me,
Yet you would looſe me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Looſe thee, Terraefilius? I'd advance thee.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thus to advance me, is to caſt me down;
Honeſty dares not lurk too near a Crown:
Policy undermines and ruines her:
Truth's an unwelcome Gueſt unto a King,
Whoſe ears have been the Inns of flattery,
Who never yet knew one truth of himſelf,
Or of his people. (Pardon my honeſt bluntneſs.)
And next conſider, if a man that knows
His duty binds him ſpeak his honeſt thoughts
T'inform his Prince of thoſe abuſe his ear,
And let him know his Peoples Grievances,
Can be a Grateful Favourite.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You muſt learn to Temporize.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Yes, be a Dog, and fawn upon each Lord; be injured, and give thanks; that is the thriving way: never ſpeak a truth, but when it is injurious; detract from true deſerts, and praiſe ſhallow great ones to their ruine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thou haſt the Theory, now try to practiſe.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: To be a Knave, a Politick Courtier; had I ſomewhat of the Fool too, they were very fortunate properties.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Although the Place ſeem ſuch an Antipode
Unto thy honeſt Nature, when thou know'ſt
My Intereſt urgeth my Commands, thou'lt flee
Swiſter then Lightning to perform my wiſh;
I know thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Were the Devil there, as Vices are his Agents, your intereſt would make me dare him too; and to promote it, vanquiſh him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Thy bluntneſs ſavours much of manly truth;
I 'll therefore uſe no further circumſtance,
But open the very ſoul of my deſigne
In placing thee at Court; which is, to finde
Out ſuch as are my enemies, and do
Infect my Fathers Soul with Jealouſie,
Inſinuating to his fearful thoughts
My Popularity. Which when thou haſt
Diſcovered, at leiſure we'll contrive
Their overthrow. Two of thoſe Slaves are now
Within the level of my juſt Revenge;
But ſo endear'd unto my Fathers Soul,
He'd think't a violence unto himſelf,
Should we but touch them.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Give me, Sir, their Names;
I'll mark them out for Hell immediately.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You ſhall have fit Directions. — You can't
Be ignorant how I have ſuffered,
And ſtill ſuffer through my Fathers weakneſs;
Of whom I now am rather fear'd, then lov'd:
The many Penances I've undergone
To gain the good Opinion of the King,
Muſt likewiſe be familiar to your thoughts,
Who can beſt witneſs the obſcurity
In which I 've liv'd; how much below my birth;
Wedding my ſelf unto a ſolitude
Little beſeeming ſuch a Kingdomes Heir,
All to regain the Kings Opinion
Of my Loyalty: A thing impoſſible,
Unleſs by Policy I could remove
Thoſe brace of Leeches that do hourly feed
Upon my Fathers weakneſs; His Aged Fears.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I'm bound to ſerve you. Did your Highneſs know
How loth I am to leave you, what a conteſt
There's grown between my Duty and my Love,
You'd ſurely pity me: But I ſerve you,
Though I'm baniſht from you, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I ſee you'll prove a Courtier; let's invent
The apteſt form now to prefer thee in:
For ſhould my Father learn thou cam'ſt from me,
He'd never truſt, but think it a deſigne
Upon his Perſon. Haſt been ſeen in Court?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Never, my Lord: nor do I think my ſelf within the verge of knowledge, ſince my transformation from a Mendicant in Buff, to a Silken Favourite.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis well: but yet I fear, although thy birth.
Was mean, thy Soul and Education both
Too Noble are to perſonate ſo baſe
A ſpirit,
As muſt endear thee to my Fathers love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Doubt me not; love makes all ſervice eaſie.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: But thou'rt to play a part ſo oppoſite
Unto thy Genius, thou't ne'er humour it.
Can'ſt act a Coward, a Slave, as timoroue
As a Virgin-Bride, lying ſuſpended
'Twixt her hopes and fears, in expectation
Of her a norous Groom?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: A Coward, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Yes, a wiſe cautious Coward; a formal
Coxcomb, thou never entereſt my Fathers
Books elſe, nor ſo much credit gain'ſt to do
Me good: my Father entertains all ſuch
About his Perſon for ſecurity:
His valiant Guard wait at the Palace-gate,
Not daring to truſt them nearer his Perſon.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Your Highneſs makes me wonder.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: To ſuch a wonder Age hath brought the King;
More my misfortune: wilt counterfeit
This Perſonage?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I'll more then counterfeit to ſerve you; I'll be
The thing you wiſh.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Receive in writing theſe Directions then,
And fail not (as you love your Prince) to act
Accordingly.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: This is the ſquare I'll rule my actions by.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Let's then by execution give life
To our deſigne; extend a Princely Arm,
And make thoſe Sycophants this Maxime know,

l.hi: 'Tis dangerous to be a Princes Foe.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: VVE have a fine time on't i'faith, to be ſole Companions, Favourites and Chamber-fellows to the King.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Chamberlains, and chief Gentlemen of the Chamber? we are Totum in Toto, or Fact-Totums.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Not too much Latine, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: For indeed all things paſs through our hands; and therefore it is reaſon we ſhould have a feeling in 't.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: How happy were we, to be born patient Gentlemen! not to have one angry Planet raign at our Nativities! not one ſcruple of Choler in both our Compoſitions.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Choler? Thou Ruby-fac'd Gentleman with a Carbunkled Noſe, I do contemn thee: I'll not give a ruſh for thee as the time goes; for thou art more out of faſhion then Picketde-vaunt Beards, or Plain-dealing at Court; and more ridiculous then Dancing to a Dead man, that ſees not the Mufick.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Fighting Valour, Voſtre ſervittur, you muſt not come within the ſmell of the Court now, and yet we are valiant too; for true Valour conſiſts in ſuffering.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Right: for if a Blow or a Kick will do a friend a kindneſs, let him take it, and be gone: if he be actively valiant in ſtriking, we will be more paſſively valiant in bearing, and oppoſe Fleſh to Fleſh, the Cheek to the Palm: for if he uſe the Batton, he's a Coward, and not valiant by Nature, becauſe he refuſes the uſe of Natural Weapons.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Which the Lyon, and other valiant Animals, employ.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: True: but thanks to our good Kings peaceable temper, we are freed from ſuch unnatural Fencers.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: And from the Natural too, prais'd be the patient Stars: they were both a continual torment to us in our days of adverſity. I could never keep my Curls in order; for the roaring of ſome Drum-headed Raskal or other would make them ſtare, and ſtand an end.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: That affliction could I bear; but when they tore Hair and Ears up by the roots, it requir'd a treble-fortified patience.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Oh, but the Villainous Kick given by the Horn'd ſhooe!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: That faſhion was invented in the City, and came from head to foot immediately: but the durty ſhooe do I exclaim againſt; it hath ſpoil'd me many a Sattin Hoſe.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: But now thanks to our generoſity in ſuffering, we have overcome our griefs, to the great grief of our Offendors, who dayly come with Cap in hand to ſue to us for favour.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Whilſt we delay their ſuits, and make them participate of our vertue.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Patience, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Twas that I was going to ſay: therefore 'tis fit now we are called to the Helm, Brother, (mark me) to the management of State-affairs, we ſhould be grateful to the vertue that hath exalted us.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Patience.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Still thou takeſt the word out of my mouth: A bearing Patience, Brother: (obſerve me) I have a deſigne to bring it in faſhion; for I conceive it very advantagious and profitable to the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: As how, dear Brother?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If you mark it, for 'tis a State-point: Bearing is the cauſe of Advancement, Peace and Defence to a Commonwealth; of Advancement in us, who whilome were the dregs, and are now become the very cream of the Commonwealth, and ſwim atop. Patience is a certain cauſe of Peace, for it makes the Citizen bear with his Wife, whilſt ſhe is bearing the Courtier: ſo every man bears one with another. Laſtly, it is a defence to the Commonwealth: for it chiefly cauſeth the generation of her Defendor.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Learnedly argued, Brother! What Fleſh can ſay more in praiſe of patient bearing? Undertake thou the faſhion amongſt the men, and let me alone to perſwade the Women; they have a natural faculty in it. But mum: Enter Valerio, Princeſs. Here comes the Princeſs and Valerio, whoſe Phyſiognomy is more terrible then an apparition of Satan, with a viſible Cloven foot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: His looks congeal my very blood; my heart is but one lump of Ice.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: But for the priviledge of the Peace, I durſt not come within the ſcent of his Valour, I thank my fear,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yonder's my Miſtreſs too; and if his very aſpect have not conjur'd down all my affections, and laid the Devil flat, may I never riſe to the Council-board.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: By this cudgell'd Carcaſe, ſhe's a dainty morſel of Mans fleſh: Oh that I had her in place where —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How thou ſwell'ſt at the ſight of a handſome Woman!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe hath eyes, whoſe ſparkling Glances invite a man to Leudneſs. Prethee let's Court her to the next Lobby; my thoughts are Fornicators already.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou wantſt a Cooling Julep; faith Brother you muſt purvey elſewhere; this Lady is ſelected for a lawful affection.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: No monopolizing, Brother: if I can get a conſent before thee, I'll make bold with the firſt cut.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Howe'er, I'll venture on the invitation; ſhe's too honeſt for thy purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I would fain ſee an honeſt Woman; but Miracles are ceaſt ſure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I dare not nouriſh the bold thoughts of love,
Yet ſtill I muſt admire you, ſtill adore you
As a Star above me; a happineſs
Like heaven, in this life not to be obtain'd,
Though wiſht for, yet there after good actions
Through th' Port of Death we may at laſt arrive,
But to the accompliſhment of my deſires,
I fear never: how can I fear a thing
I dare not hope for?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You are (my Lord) too cruel to your ſelf,
Too ſuperſtitious in your love, to which
Altho' I dare give no encouragement,
Not being my own Diſpoſer, might I
Adviſe, it ſhould be conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam,
Could I be guilty of ſo greate crime,
Or Heaven be ſo cruel to impoſe
(For ſecret ſins) ſo high a puniſhment,
As make me know a change in my Devotions
To your Grace, yet your Vertuous Counfel
Would ſtrengthen and reanimate my love
To ſuch a vigorous perfection,
It would appear invincible to all
The incounters of an adverſe fortune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You're very confident of your affection.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your Goodneſs (Madam) did firſt give it birth:
But if I have offended, pardon me,
And I will teach my tongue forget that Name,
That Divine Name of Love. I 'd not offend
Your Vertue willingly: but if a ſervice,
Pretending nothing but from your merit,
A pure flame, free from the ſmoak of luſt,
Zealous Devotions, no ways counterfeit,
Can pretend to the Character of Love,
Pray let me read it in a ſmile: You are
In this too bountiful, and I in the
Requeſt (I fear) too impudent: if ſo
With a frown you chide away my Soul whilſt dying
On your hand, I vow my ſelf your Martyr.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How he moves me! I have too much Woman:
My Lord! ſee how unmovedly he ſtands!
Juſt like Loves Statue, and as lovely. Sure
He's tranſported in his thoughts: How his Fancie
Labours! 'twere ſin beyond a cruelty to ſcorn
Such love, which in a ſweet, yet negligent
Diſtraction, diſplays both Truth and Paſſion.
But he recovers!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What a Paradiſe hath my thoughts enjoyed!
What Seas of Pleaſures hath my Fancie waded!
Moſt Divine Power of Love! thy Joys and Griefs
Are both inſcrutable, and not to be
Comprehended.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How do you do, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Very exceeding well, never better:
Surely Sickneſs dares not approach me now,
Now you are preſent, who are both my life
And health, indeed my All: for leſs cannot
Expreſs you; nor that at full.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You ſet (my Lord) too great a value on
A worth that's borrowed from the Barren Duſt
Of Anceſtors: Their peculiar Vertues
Made them Kings, my Fortune me a Princeſs:
I might as well been born the neglected
Iſſue of a Shepherdeſs, and paſt as
Unregarded; your Lordſhip then (I doubt)
Would ſcarce have thought my Vertue a full Dowry,
My Chaſtity a Nobleneſs in Nature.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How much you wrong my thoughts, (Madam!) my Love's
No common flame wedded to Luſt, or to
Ambition; it is your Soul, your Soul
Of Vertue I am raviſht with: had it
Inhabited the coarſeſt blackeſt earth
Affrick did ere produce, 'twould have rendred
It Divine, and through that Sable Cloud
Caſt forth its glorious Beams of brightneſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Continue ſtill a Preſident for Lovers;
Steer them a courſe to everlaſting love,
Immortal as the Soul. Tell them, Beauty
Is fading; ſuch will be their love if plac'd
On her; Greatneſs unſtable, no ſecure
Prop to build it on. Vertue's the Pillar
That will never fail: She's your Advocate,
And pleads (my Lord) your intereſt in my heart:
Doat on her ſtill; for ſhe'll deſerve your love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have ever done ſo, (Madam) doated
On you; but with ſuch reverence, ſuch a
Becoming duty, as beſt might ſuit my
Meanneſs, and your great Birth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Continue conſtant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Continue conſtant? excellent Motto!
Thou ſhalt be ingrav'd in laſting Characters
About my heart, and excho thence
Thoſe ſacred words, until my tongue forget
All frivolous Diſcourſe; onely her name
Shall intermixedly make up
Loves Harmony, whilſt dayly I admire
Thoſe Blazing Stars which ſet my heart on fire.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Prince, Terraefilius in a plain ſimple dreſs.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: IF thou canſt ſuit thy Garb unto thy dreſs,
Thou gain'ſt acceſs and credit with the King.
But Terraefilius, do not forget
The ends for which I plac'd thee there, to work
For my advantage, and to plead my cauſe
Like a double-fee'd Advocate, which muſt
Be with ſucceſs; the Kings Aged Weakneſſes
Being of ſuch an eaſie mold, they take
Impreſſions, good or bad, as thoſe about
Him ſtamp on his Belief.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: For the future, it ſhall bear the Signet
Of your Vertue, which I'll impreſs ſo deep
Into his Soul, that Age, nor eating time
Shall never raſe. I'll let him know how ſweet
A hope he hath for to ſucceed him: how
Noble a Son, how generous a Prince,
How full of duty and of humble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Thou wilt in this ſo far oblige us, that
I ſhall eſteem my Favours paſt but Trifles.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I'm richly recompenſed in your Princely Love!
Continue me but there, I wiſh no greater
Fortune.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Would I could take thee nearer to my Soul,
Thou art ſo good: but being already at height
In my affection, I will raiſe thee to
An equal highth in Fortune: when I raign,
'Tis Terraefilius that muſt command.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I am (my Lord) your Vaſſal, born to ſerve,
Not to oblige you: yet I would not change
My bondage to be a Monarch; ſo much
I prize your love and ſervice!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I know thou loveſt us, and need no farther
Argument to confirm the truth. But now
To my Deſigne: This leads to the Preſence,
I muſt commit thee to thy fortune; for
I dare advance no further, it would breed
Too much ſuſpicion: you know your task.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And will perform't with all fidelity.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis in thy power to oblige thy Prince;
And to miſtruſt, were too much injury,
Where I have found ſo much fidelity

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I were too baſe a Villain to deceive
So generous a Prince: Your confidence
Would make a Traytor Loyal, but on me
Meer Gratitude doth put a double eye.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: May the Gods favour our deſignes!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: They're oblig'd to favour Juſtice, Sir.
Poor Prince! I pity him: I ſee Content
Is ſeldome converſant with high Eſtates;
Moſt Vertuous Souls are injur'd moſt by Fates.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: FEllow Malcigno! let us be watchful, vigilant and careful in our Office; the King is upon entrance, and relies upon our honeſty for his Safe-guard.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Therefore it is ſafe we ſearch each corner wherein Treaſon may lurk.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What a brace of Baboons are theſe? fitter to keep Centinal at a Ladies Cloſet, then at a Kings Bed chamber.— But I muſt try my fortune, and accoſt them: Worſhipful Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Ha! what Fellow's that ſpeaks to us with his Juſtice of Peace his Title?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Right Worſhipful Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So, he riſes a note, but hath not attain'd our ſtile.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Brother, take no notice of him; Auſterity and Gravity are the Eſſence of Greatneſs and Place.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let us then walk by him with as much contempt as a begging Spaniard refuſes an Alms before witneſs.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What Musk-cats are theſe, to guide a tottering State, whoſe Wiſdome is meer Formality; Honeſty, Baſeneſs; and greateſt Vertue, Cowardiſe? But I muſt temporize with theſe State-Leeches: Right Honourable, I have an humble ſuit to your Honours.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: An humble ſuit to your Honours? This is ſomewhat like.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: That your Honours would deign to prefer me to the King, as a perſon dignified with the Vertue Patience, which his Gracious Pleaſure hath newly rendred a Majeſtical Vertue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Fellow, I fear thou haſt not undergone all the tryal of that magnanimous Vertue.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Brother, you ſay right: for thoſe Carbuncles in his face denote Choler, heat of Liver, and Inflammations of Anger: therefore, Fellow, we cannot; it is abſolutely againſt. Allegiance to ad nit thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How many tryals of patience haſt thou paſt through?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Various ſufferings, Sir, and Militant afflictions; as, the Baſtinado, the Horn'd-ſhooe-kick, the Twinge by the Noſe, the Lug by the Ear, and penetrating Laſh; all which I have born with patience, becauſe I would not ſtain my Honor.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Certes, Brother, this Fellow hath Vertue in him.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: If I could but ſee Golden Proofs, I ſhould believe: But to introduce a Fellow to our capacity, (do you conceive me, Brother?) is no ſmall kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'd be of your Opinion, had the Fellow Wit or Policy; but he's a Fool, you may ſee by his Garb.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: The fool may chance to colt you, rather uncolt you: caſt you from the Saddle of preferment. But I muſt buy my place, I ſee that: there's no Courtier hath ſo little Wit, but he can take money for an Office. Gentlemen, preſuming you have conſidered my aptitude for the Kings ſervice, and that your reſolutions are in my favour, I take the boldneſs to preſent you this parcel of Crowns.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Now we underſtand him, theſe are the onely Pleaders.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Next to Women, Brother.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Women, I grant, are very prevalent: I ſaw the Fellows aptitude before: if you mark it, he hath an ingenious countenance; we'll prefer him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Content: to ſay truth, the weight of Government is too ponderous for two. Come, Fellow, and be obedient, thou art made for ever: if otherwiſe, we will take the Prop of our favour from thee, and expoſe thee to the perils of fortune.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I ſhall be ſtill your Creature.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: He will thrive, I warrant him; he hath learnt to flatter great Ones.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Good Dog-Whelps, you that ſell your Princes ſmiles
For Crowns, would for a ſum of Angels ſell
His Crown, and Life to boot: Such ſweet Engines
(Giving a handſome opportunity)
Might transform a Polititian to
A Traytor; which proves this Axiome true,

l.hi: That Prince can ne'er be ſafe who much depends
On Knaves for Counſel, and makes Cowards Friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: DO you all know him?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Know him, my Liege? better then our ſelves: an honeſt Fellow, an' pleaſe your Majeſty; and ſo holy, he hath almoſt worn out his fingers ends with dropping Beads.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: He prays ſo continually, the Devil's grown weary to diſturb his Meditations.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Did you but ſee him at his Orizons, you'd ſwear he enticed Heaven by his amorous poſtures to an embrace. I never courted Wench with half ſuch an Alphabet of Geſtures.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis well, it doth become your care to place ſuch near our Perſon; for we relie upon your faiths: I don't affect theſe Men-killers ſtil'd Valiant; they are cruel, and gain a reputation by ſpilling Humane Blood.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This Gentleman's ſo merciful, he'll not crack a Lowſe for fear of ſpilling it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What doth our Daughter think of this new Courtier?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I think he may be worth your favour, Sir:
If one may judge by looks, his countenance
Befriends him: truly I think him faithful:
Nor can I fancie any man ſo cruel,
So much at enmity at leaſt with Heaven,
As to wiſh harm unto their Soveraign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your Innocence let's you not ſee the dangers
Threaten us: Our ears are every where;
Nor want we power to prevent
All thoſe deſignes of blood that menace us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Boody deſignes indeed! ſure ſuch evils
Cannot inhabit in a ſubject Soul.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor Girl! ſhe weeps: I wiſh her Brother were
Of this ſoft ſtrain: but he's all Martial,
And bears Deſtruction in his very looks,
To Us, and to our Kingdome. He might ſtay
Till Nature force me to reſigne it up
To his Protection, without ſeeking
Thus to encroach upon my ſubjects loves.
We ſha'nt long trouble him: Me thinks our Age,
Did not the Law impoſe a double tie
Of Son and Subject, might incline his heart
To due obedience; but Nought works on him.
A Crown's eſteem'd a thing of ſo much weight,
Men ſeldome weigh by what means 'tis obtain'd.
Treaſon we never do for juſt allow,
But when ſhe pearches on a Monarchs brow.
When I am dead, none dare the Deed diſown;
The Prince will juſtifie it by my Throne.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Doth he uſe to talk to himſelf thus?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: 'Tis his dayly exerciſe: for he'll admit no company but the Princeſs and us; and we are commonly ſo buſied for his ſafety, he cannot think it ſafe to trouble us with ſo much talk.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange melancholy hath poſſeſt him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Your Majeſties Creature: I'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: He call'd for Caliſto:
Did you obſerve? I like it not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your fears are now too buſie: if the King uſe him for other then a Jeſter, ne'er truſt my Policy.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Let's have a care, for favour makes men bolder:
I would be loth he caper o'er my ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: ARe you oft troubled with theſe Poetical fits?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faireſt of Ladies, did you never know it,
How in a dream I was ordain'd a Poet?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Not I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then liſten pray, the ſtory ſtraight will follow:
Being one night drunk, and dreaming of Apollo,
That Riming god, I in a rapture fell,
Which made my Buttons crack, my Body ſwell;
And in Poetick fury by exclaims,
I call'd the Muſes by their proper names:
The Furies all, 'tis truth that I do tell ye,
I ſtraight did feel to rumble in my Belly;
Furies within, the Muſes nine without me;
You may imagine how I laid about me.
Out-thundring Jove, with fancies that I ſtole,
And frighted Phoebus with an Hyperbole
Which was too high for to be underſtood,
Or of my ſelf or him: but ſure 'twas good;
For ſuddainly, as I do think, did follow
My Inſtallation by the god Apollo;
Who roſe reſplendently from off his ſeat,
With ſuch a vaſt illuminary heat,
As put me ſomething in a ſweat.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: The laſt Verſe wants a foot; lend it a crutch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No wonder; ſure the Verſe was at a ſtand,
Wanting a foot; for then I us'd my hand
To wipe away the ſweat from off my face:
The heat my pardon pleads in ſuch a caſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: And juſtly too: me thinks you ſtill are hot:
Put not your Muſe unto ſo hard a task:
Pray tell your tale in Proſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Truly I am none of thoſe
That knows how to ſpeak in Proſe:
Since my Inſtalment Verſe doth flow
From me wheth'r I will or no:
Therefore if you'll hear the ſtory
In my Language, I am for ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So you'll be brief, (my Lord) I am content,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Apollo riſen, (as I ſaid before)
In his right-hand a Cypreſs Garland bore,
In's left a Laſh, by which he did preſage,
That with my Satyres I ſhould ſcourge the Age.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then you are much Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am all the parts of Poeſie and love;
Pray hear me out,
I'll clear all doubt
Your Criticiſms can object or move.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: 'Tis pity ſo brave a Fellow ſhould be fool'd by fancie,
And Valour wedded to ſuch indiſcretion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Silence, Madam, in a Woman
Is a Vertue, but not common.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Proceed; I am moſt attentive.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then Phoebus put the Garland on my head,
And ſtraight by him my Deſtiny was read,
That I ſhould languiſh much for my firſt Love:
But if to me ſhe too unkind did prove,
Each Lady that did hear a Verſe of mine,
At firſt ſhould love, but if refus'd, ſhould pine.
'Tis you I firſt affect.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yeeld love for love.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Oh excellent Poetical Courtſhip!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Leſt your whole Sex do theſe diſaſters prove.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Moſt dire and terrible!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now if you can affect me, I pray ſhew it
To him Apollo ſtil'd the Cypreſs Poet.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: My Lord, you are all affected.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: By all affected, and refus'd by you,
Were in my Cypreſs Wreath to mingle Rue.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How now, my Lord?
You ſpend your time in Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: A Poet, Madam, always is in love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But is't true? I heard that Miracle, and wanted faith.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Moſt true: he can both ſeign and rime.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I thought his Lordſhip had ſcarce wit to be guilty of ſuch a folly. Caliſto, what think you? doth not his face betray him for a Lord?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: More then a Poet, Madam: for me thinks he wants much of their crabbedneſs in his countenance: he looks not as if he had lately contracted his brows in a Purſe-net for a Conceit: beſides, his Hair grows thick upon the Temples; which Poets ſtill tug off, with pumping for inventions.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: But his are free; his Verſe all unconſtrain'd:
For he hath quite forgot his Mother-tongue,
And Metre flows more plentifully from
His lips, then Claret from a Conduit-pipe
At a Coronation.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure he's inſpir'd, Livia: he was wont
To be content with Proſe, altho' it came
A little ſhort of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Indeed he us'd a Martial bluntneſs, Madam:
But give him ſtill his due, he was a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sure the Wench loves him.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Your Highneſs is deceiv'd; 'tis he loves me;
And yet I pity him, that for my ſake
He ſhould incur ſo great a Lunacy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: As love? is that a madneſs?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Oft-times it ſelf: but in a Martial Scull,
And joyn'd with Poetry, a double Lunacy.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: See how his Muſe labours! he ſtands as if he were
Caſting Figures, or conjuring for Verſes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hieroglyphick love, that with Geometrical are,
Takes the dimenſion of each Triangle heart.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Thoſe words lay hard upon his Stomack.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They were bad of digeſtion towards bed-time:
Ha, ha, ha! he turns: his eyes are fixt on Livia.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: He'd make a gallant Setter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A pretty Puppy for a Ladies Lap.

l.hi: Is it your Nature, Lady, or your Will,
That makes you cruell ſtill?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: My Will.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: He varies too much his humour to be mad •

l.hi: Will you be then 'gainſt Reaſon ſtill unkind;
And count my Paſſion Wind?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Winde.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well ſung eccho.

l.hi: Wind is but Air, and with a puff is paid:
Will you ſtill live a Maid?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: A Maid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then by this puff of ſcorn you have betray'd
Your Sex to ruine: had you my love cheriſht,
You had been ſafe, and none of them had periſht.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: He can vail out of Tune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But not in Proſe.
This Fellow's humour might become the Stage
Exceeding well, but that it would be thought.
Too much extravagant. To what a heighth
Of madneſs may fancy bear a man!

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Madam, you miſt the beſt; I had the whole
Relation of his Inſtalment.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come in, and tell the ſtory; ſuch harmleſs mirth
Beſt pleaſes: I ſhall be mindful of my Brother's
Buſineſs; he gives you a noble character.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Ever a Slave unto your Vertues, Madam:
I would I were your Maſter! Rebellious
Thoughts, how dare ye aſſume a voice to give
Your ſelves a ſound articulate? Die, die,
And with you periſh all my fonder hopes,
Grounded upon ambitious Policy.
My honeſt thoughts, keep guard upon my heart;
For love doth ſeek to undermine the fort,
And ſo betray me to ingratitude.
Still the infection ſeizes on my heart;
Love like a Poiſon ſpreads its Leproſie;
Which will too ſoon I fear corrupt my ſoul,
For it already doth my thoughts controul.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: THat was Caliſto ſure that parted hence?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: It was, an' like your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Send him to us, and be you diligent
In keeping watch the while for our ſafety.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: We ſhall, Sir: I like not this familiarity,
Brother, we muſt rid us of this fear.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We'll finde occaſions to diſgrace him, fear not:
But to our task.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My ſafety bids me try him ere I truſt:
For I perceive him of a ſubtler mold
Then all my other Servitors. He's fit
(If I ſind him honeſt) to be truſted
In the full management of thoſe affairs
Neareſt concern us; our proper ſafety;
And next, the peace and welfare of the State:
Both which are threatned by the Prince; a Son
In Title, in Duty a meer ſtranger:
Where I ſhould love, there I have cauſe to fear;
But what I want in Son, I have in Heir:
Yet he ſhall ſtay his time, maugre his ſpirit;
'Tis juſt his Father die 'fore he inherit.

l.hi: Caliſto!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: My Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You promis'd us when laſt we did diſcourſe,
To give us your opinion of our Son:
We have given you time to recollect your knowledge;
Therefore ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Sir, your requeſt is of ſo deep concern,
And I ſo little in his nature verſt,
I never durſt have undertook the task, which to diſpute
Had not your dread Commands
Were impudence in me) conſtrain'd me to't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We like your honeſt caution; ſpeak your
Thoughts freely.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You give a Noble freedome, which I'll uſe
As beſt becomes a ſubject that ſpeaks truth.
You have a Son ſo full of Piety,
So enrich'd with Wiſdome, Valour, indeed all
Thoſe Vertues which adorn a Noble Prince,
Or Kings may hope for in their Succeſſours,
To make their Kingdome happy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this through ignorance or love? I'll ſound him:
Caliſto, thou doſt flatter him, baſely
Belye his Vices: believe it, he's more proud
Then Lucifer; in Ambition greater
Then the Giants that threatned Heaven:
For Cruelty, no Tygres equal him;
He wears a bloody mantle o'er his thoughts,
And underneath obſcurely lie involv'd
The darkeſt Policies Hell e'er contriv'd.
He well may term himſelf the ſcourge o' th' Gods;
For he's his Fathers terrour, his diſquiet:
How can I be a King, and fear? Can Nature
On my Prerogative ſo far prevail,
To make me live in bondage to a Son?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: He's much incens'd: Policy bids comply.
I ſee your Majeſty's much better read
In the obſcure Volume of the Princes heart
Then I; in which appears ſuch gentle mildneſs,
So intermixt with duty to your ſelf,
As might deceive a wiſer man then I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This Fellow's honeſt ſure.
All's but Hypocriſie, and meer Deceit;
Rebellion ſtill hath worn Religions Cloak:
Worſt Acts are fac'd with Piety. Believe't,
Policy hath taught the Prince firſt what to ſeem,
Then what to be: but I know all his haunts;
There's not a corner of his heart lies hid
From my diſcovery: his ſecret Plots
Appear as plain as the unclouded Sun
In the Meridian.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How men may be abus'd! I do proteſt
The World believeth him a Miracle
Of Vertue, and thence erect a pity
To his Perſon: ſome are ſo bold to term
You cruel, others unjuſt unto his worth;
Which is by all admir'd: I cannot blame
Your Majeſty to fear, though much I grieve
You ſhould have cauſe of fear; eſpecially
From him, whereon your Kingdome doth erect:
Such hopes: but your Majeſty is wiſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We will begin to be ſo: now thou perceiv'ſt
Our injuries.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: With too much grief.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Honeſt Caliſto, thou ſhalt ſhare our boſome:
We intend this night for to ſecure the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your Majeſty's a miracle of Wiſdome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We have intelligence he is to ſup
With the Duke of Calabria to night;
A notable Favourer of his faction.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Heaven I hope favours your Majeſty,
And then you need not fear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fear (Caliſto) ſhall henceforth looſe her Name;
'Tis Action now that muſt ſecure us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You are an Oracle unto your ſelf,
And need no ſecond counſel.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is not ſafe to ſtroke a Lyons Whelp
Whence once he doth begin to finde his ſtrength;
Much leſs to truſt ſo popular a Prince,
Molded by War to every act of Blood,
With liberty, and all the peoples hearts.
Thoſe Princes by a Politick compaſs ſteer,
Who ſtill ſecure what they have cauſe to fear.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: So, I'm a Favourite already: ſure
The Air o' th' Court's unwholſom, and infects,
I could not elſe ſo ſoon become a Knave;
Nay worſe, a Traytor to my Princes truſt;
And if that worſe may be, ungrateful too
To a man that rais'd me from the duſt, from whence
He ſnatcht me up to plant me in his breaſt:
And for this good muſt I now cut his throat?
The time requires it: Pox on Machiavel,
I had been honeſt had I ne'er read thee:
But now the Devil chalks me out a way
To be a King, my Vertue can't reſiſt
So rich a bait: Ambition whiſpers me;
How near were Terraefilius to a Throne,
Could he but make the Princeſs once his own!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: VVHat haſte you make away!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Buſineſs calls loud upon me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, uſe your pleaſure, Sir, ſince I am grown
So great a burthen to your thoughts: you ſeem
Diſtaſted with my company, which us'd
To be ſo pleaſing, (at leaſt you made me
Think ſo) Melancholy durſt not approach
Your heart whilſt you poſſeſt it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtill as grateful; and, Clariana,
More precious to my ſoul then ever.
I muſt' confeſs ſome melancholy thoughts
Perplex my minde, and raiſe diſturbances
Within my ſoul, I know no reaſon for't.
I never yet (to my remembrance)
Surprized was with ſuch a ſuddain fear:
My whole frame ſhakes, as if my innocent Soul
Were guilty of ſome crime ſhe durſt not think on.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I fear'd ſomewhat relating to my ſelf
Had rais'd that ſtormy weather in your looks:
I would not willingly through ignorance
Offend a Perſon, to whom knowingly
Love hath not left me power to wiſh ill.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It is not in thy power to offend;
But you are too indulgent to your fears:
Would I could dreſs my face in ſuch a look
As might ſtill give aſſurance of my love,
And ſo kill ſuſpicion. Clariana,
It is the miſery of Lovers ſtill
To fancie or too little, or too much:
They conſter frowns, and miſinterpret ſmiles
For fears or hopes, as love their fancy guides.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Love knows no reaſon, therefore is govern'd
By appearances: beſides, the face is term'd
The Index of the minde, wherein's diſcern'd
Each paſſion of the Soul: Gladneſs and Joy
Are there enthron'd, and circled in with ſmiles:
Diſtaſte appears in Frowns; Anger and Rage
Still ſhooteth from the eye, and ſo doth ſcorn:
But Melancholy is too bold a Gueſt,
Engroſſing all theſe Lodgings to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: This were an Art worth ſtudying: had men
So fair a Book as your face to read it,
They would out-ſtare Aſtronomers, and be
More wakeful then a Nurſe-keeper that had
Newly learnt to watch with her eyes open.
The News? —

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: This Letter to your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, is he gone? — Oh my Prophetick fear!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How fares my Lord the Prince?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Read, Clariana, read; and tell me then
If I have cauſe to grieve: Terraefilius
Says there the King intends to ſecure us,
Immediately to coop and cage me up.
What then his Paraſites may work him to,
Let all men judge that have a grain of ſence.
Experience doth make me juſtly fear,

l.hi: A Princes Priſon and his Grave are near.

sp.l: Alas, poor Clariana! Why doſt ſpend
Thoſe precious Tears in vain? Preſerve them
To embalm my Hearſe: for they are uſeleſs now,
Could they diſſolve a Rock of Adamant;
For the Kings heart's a much more harden'd ſubſtance.
Here comes thy aged Father weeping too,
As if his Tears held counſel with my fate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Flee, flee, my Lord! and by eſcape prevent
The fury of the King, whoſe Officers
Are making down the Street to apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why let them come: my innocence is ſo
Secure a Guard, I cannot fear.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Vertue may be by Violence oppreſt:
Oh good my Lord, ſeek to preſerve your ſelf;
You do not know the ruine threatens you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is no idle fear; there are ſtrange whiſpers;
And how far the Kings jealouſie may work
Upon him, none but the Gods can tell: We'ave
All cauſe to doubt, ſince from his love and counſels
All worthy Souls are baniſht. You he hath
Baniſht too; you, whom he ought to eſteem
The chiefeſt Pillar to ſupport his State.
But we have no time for Arguments, my Lord;
I hear the Officers.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh hear me on my knees! Liſten to her
You oft have ſtil'd Commandreſs of your heart;
She begs you would be kinde unto your ſelf;
If not unto your ſelf, unto the State,
Whoſe welfare on your ſafety doth depend.
If all this cannot move, yet pity me:
Nay, I'll not riſe until you grant my boon.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I can deny thee nothing: Riſe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh give me then your ſafety by your flight!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My Lord, you muſt not now delay: to horſe;
And with a winged ſpeed let's to Calabria:
We have all an intereſt in you, and dare not
Let you periſh.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Your goodneſs doth o'ercome me: nothing grieves me,
But thus to part with thee, my Clariana:
It is an Exile worſe then death: but Fate
Muſt be obey'd. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Take all my Prayers, and choiceſt Wiſhes with you,
Whilſt I remain at home the wofull'ſt Maid
That love ere brought acquainted with miſhap.
But I muſt dry my eyes, and for a time
Take truce with grief. Here comes the Officers.
Fortune aſſiſt my Lord in his eſcape,
And I'll forgive thee all thy treacheries,
And with a Stoicks Patience ſuſtain
The Princes abſence.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Yonder's the daughter, ſhe's lawful prize:
I'll ſeize on her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How bath my guiltleſs ſelf offended, that
You dare commit this Rape? Pray let me know
My crime: if by Authority you act,
The Law preſcribes no puniſhment but to
Offenders.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: We are not bound to give account; 'tis the Kings
Pleaſure, and as a ſubject you muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Come, Jaylors, lead; I'll uſe for my defence
What you could never boaſt, bright Innocence.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Terraefilius, Juliana, Livia, Frangypane, Luſſurio, Maligno, Valerio.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: THe Prince his flight was happy 'bove my wiſh:
Had he complotted with me my deſignes,
He could not more advance them. The fearful King
(By this convinc'd of his Diſloyalty)
Hath levied forces to reduce the Prince,
And nam'd (by my advice) Valerio
For General. Thus hath my Policy
At one blow remov'd a Rival here at
Home, to promote my intereſt abroad.
He'll either overcome the Prince, or die
I' th' enterprize: I know his Valour well;
Either will make for me: for both muſt fall
Low as the Grave, before I can aſcend
This wiſh'd-for Throne, or gain Juliana's love:
That's the grand wheel whereon my Plots do move.
See, here ſhe comes! Mirth triumphs in her face:
sp.stage: Enter Juliana, Livia, Frangypane, Luſſurio, Maligno.
sp.l: She's ignorant her Lover is advanc'd:
But I'll obſerve.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What makes him flee me thus?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: For fear, Madam, you ſhould undergo a puniſhment threatned all our Sex, for my neglect of his good parts.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We'll give this hour to mirth; I'll proſecute the humour.
Sweet Frangypane, how affable he looks!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This did I ſtill foreſee: Pray look not on me,
Leſt a Judgement fall ſuddainly upon thee.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: His rime makes him very familiar; fine foolery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: For Phoebus ſwore an Oath of dreadful awe,
Soon as the ſcorn of Livia he ſaw,
In ſuch a manner he'd revenge his Poet,
That all the Sex of woman-kinde ſhould know it:
For hear, quoth he, thou Cypreſs Lawreat.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! a Cypreſs Lawrel!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You'll make him forget his Rhyme.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Though we do not intend to alter fate,
Which has thy love to Livia decreed,
Her ſcorn to thee ſhall make a thouſand bleed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A direful Sentence!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Therefore, O Princeſs, I this boon implore,
That you would never look upon me more:
For though your heart with loves ſtrong fangs were torn,
Your kindneſs I muſt ſtill return with ſcorn:
And I perceive, Oh me, ſhe drops her Glove,
A certain token that ſhe is in love.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Slaves, how dare ye at a Poet laugh,
Who can at pleaſure Cudgel with a ſtaff
Of Verſes moſt Satyrical your bodies,
Till you become bald Puppies, arrant Noddies?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Inſpire me (Muſe;) were it before a Jury,
I could no longer now contain my Fury:
Raptures, ye Slaves, within my head do rumble,
And thus their furious weights upon you tumble.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Oh good Sir! Oh my bones!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Is this baſting in Verſe, pray?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What, do you gape, and in contempt ſtill ſtand,
As if you did divide the Muſes hand?
Then 'tis convenient, Raskals, that we greet
Your Bums in meaſure with Poetick feet.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Oh Lord, Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A Pox▪ this is worſe then kicking in Proſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good Livia take him off; his humour's tedious:
Should the King come and ſee his Favourites
Corrected thus, he'd be diſpleas'd.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Sweet Seignior Frangypane!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sweet is the Name, ſince you do give it voice;
But ſweeter were it, were that Name your choice.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Here 'tis too publick to diſcover love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll wait on you to the adjacent Grove.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Pretty fooliſh paſtime this; but I have other Engins working here.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How do you finde your bodies, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: As well as beaten bodies, Madam, ſore and bruiſed:
Patient Valour is ſubject to theſe corrections.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A Pox upon Poetical feet; eſpecially when they don't run ſmooth: they gall moſt damnably, and then they come with ſuch a fury! to be incloſed in a Barrel full of Nails, and roll'd down a hill, is no torment to it.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: A meer May-game: I ſhall hate a Poet whilſt I live.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You muſt be charitable, and forgive.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Our Patience ſhall ſupply that vertue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the King enquires for you.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: He ſhall not long, if this limping pace will bear us to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam, I'm come to take my lateſt leave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your leave, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And like an humble Lover, offer on
The Altar of your hand, my faithfull'ſt Vows.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Are you to go a Voyage?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A Pilgrimage to death: for every ſtep
That contributes to the ſeparation
Of Valerio from your Princely preſence,
Leads to my grave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot reach your meaning: if my ſight
Be ſo neceſſary an ingredient
To the compoſition of your life,
You may defer the Journey.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Although, great Princeſs, you might much command
By Loves Prerogative, indeed my life,
I muſt not now obey.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You ſpeak in Parables.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis eaſily explain'd: I now muſt leave
Loves gentle Theame, and treat of nought but War:
The King hath ruin'd me with Honour, (Madam;)
Makes me a General of men abroad,
Whilſt my poor heart's at home a Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is this your woful Pilgrimage to death?
This your Miſhap? Is it the War you fear?
Hen-hearted Man! where did'ſt thy courage looſe?
Or hadſt thou ever any? Valerio.
Let me not looſe the hopes I had in thee,
To find a Man that's abſolute in all,
Courtly in Peace, and yet more ſtern in War
Then Pallas in her Martial-Robes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis not the War, nor all thoſe horrours, (Madam)
Which are Companions to a Martial life,
Can move a panick thought: 'Tis to leave you
That ſtartles me, and lays my Courage waſte:
My heart would better brook to ſtand a breach
When Death and Horrour both did hem me in,
Then one day bear the burden of your abſence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I muſt not have you thus effeminate
In your affections, forſaking Honour
To content your Eye. What Noble Spirit
Would for a Miſtreſſes fleeting ſmiles exchange
So glorious a Title? Kings need not bluſh
To wear it! A General comprehends
All Titles in it ſelf; thoſe glorious Honours
Vertue, Valour, or Deſert can merit.
Fortune hath painted you out a copious Field
To merit what your birth dares not pretend,
My Love: if you eſteem it at the rate
Your tongue ſo prodigally hath expreſt,
You'll judge it meriting one generous
Atchievement, as an evidence at leaſt
To the world my favours were beſtow'd on Vertue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Enough: your ſpeech hath ſhot into my breaſt
Another ſoul: I am your Souldier:
Though I deſpair of being ſo fortunate
To merit what all worth can ſcarce deſerve,
Your favour, I ſhall do ſomething, Madam,
(Encourag'd by your ſmiles) that may appear
Like merit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I no ways doubt it: all my diſcourſe
Was to withdraw you from Love-Lethergie,
Fondneſs, and Chamber-courtſhip. It is poor
For men to ſay they love, and give no proof
Of their affections: I would have you
Rather by actions then by words ſubdue.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: YOu muſt be ſpeedy, Sir, when Treaſon doth
Aſſume ſo bold a front to ſhew her ſelf
I' th' open field: Delays are dangerous:
So many minutes as you let them breathe
The ſweet air of repoſe, ſo many men
You arm againſt your ſelf. The Peoples love
Unto the Prince (which gives their courage wings
Soon as they hear him in a ſetled poſture)
Will move them all to flee unto his aid.
Traytors like Foxes ſhould be hunted ſtill:
Though in the chaſe of every other beaſt
The Huntſman gives a Law to ſave their life,
He never ſpares the Fox: th' application's eaſie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art a juſt Adviſer, and doſt weigh
In Wiſdomes ſcale the ſafety of thy Prince.
We have too much conſider'd, too little done:
Our Counſels henceforth ſhall be dreſt in Acts
Soon as conceiv'd. The Traytors ſhall no longer
Triumph by our ſloth. How ſtrong are we?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But yet ſix thouſand; moſt of them compell'd,
Which ſhews their ſmall affections to their King;
And how their ſouls, although their body's preſt
Unto your ſervice, wiſh your ſon Victory:
I dare not call him Prince, ſince he forſook
Allegiance to your Majeſty: before,
He was the very Idol of my ſoul;
But when he forſook Vertue, I left him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Honeſt Caliſto, we'll finde a time to recompence thy love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: If you forget, I'll finde a time my ſelf.
sp.l: Here comes my Lord Valerio; I beſeech
Your Majeſty to haſten his diſpatch:
I can't conceive you ſafe whilſt your General's in Silk.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have us'd all diligence, yet cannot learn
With any certainty which way the Prince
Hath ſteer'd his courſe: two Scouts are new return'd
As ignorant as when I ſent them forth.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: This falls unleckily; he muſt be remov'd,
Or all the Politick Wheels within this Scull
Are at a ſtand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What's to be done, Caliſto?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Why, let the Army march.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But whither?
The Station of the Prince is yet unknown.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: It is impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That frown, Caliſto, might be ſpar'd.
Pleaſe your Majeſty a word in private.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: All my deſignes are ſtrangled in their birth.
A Pox on Fortune, and her Lady Humours:
Muſt theſe dull Brains be uſeleſs in extreams,
When they ſhould be more active then a flame,
Conſume to aſhes every obſtacle
That ſtands between me and my deareſt hopes?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am convinc'd; you ſhall defer your march.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It were too much unſafe for me to march
At any diſtance from your Majeſty:
For ſoon as th' Enemy doth hear which way
I move, they may retain ſome pety force
T' allure me on, and keep me there in Play,
Whilſt their main body, nearer your ſacred
Perſon, may appear to diſturb your Peace,
And terrifie your people.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis true, our own ſecurity muſt firſt be ſtudied.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What eaſie Arguments ſeduce a t • morous Prince! I'll follow the ſtream a while, that I may turn the current with more eaſe. Maligno, the News?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Soft, Sir, 'tis for your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Prethee be leſs a States-man: come, reveal.
To me, dear Camerade, this Nicety?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: It muſt not be purchas'd with fair words; it is a News beyond the price of Gold. An' pleaſe your Majeſty!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Fie, be not impudent; you ſee the King is buſie with the General. Well, I could tell thee that concerning thy Miſtreſs might deſerve a Novelty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What, of my Livia?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And of another within thy knowledge, to whom ſhe doth more favours then ever City-wife beſtow'd upon her Husband at midnight, when ſhe had made him Cuckold the day before.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But canſt thou give me proof?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Yes, viſible proof; and that's the certaineſt: I think it concerns thee, if thou art ſo near marriage as rumour gives out.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Dear Caliſto, thou'lt oblige me thine; and for the Novelty thus, a Scout is new come in, that brings advice of
two thouſand men in Arms in Caelabria, headed by the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Enough; be gone; obſerve your Miſtreſs well: I'll keep my word: obſerve Luſſurio too; I ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I ever fear'd that Smock-ſmelling Raskal: if I had but heart enough to cut his throat, it were ſome ſatisfaction; for on my conſcience he'd make no reſiſtance: the danger would be, if the ſight of his blood ſhould turn my ſtomach, I ſhall go near to ſwoon, or elſe perfume the Palace: I'll conſider on't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is this intelligence true?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Maligno ſo affirms: the Scout's arriv'd,
And ſays he ſaw four thouſand men in Arms
All well appointed; that they did encreaſe
Their numbers dayly. I muſt ſpur his fears
With dangers (though no truths) to haſten Valerio's journey.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you eſteem it neceſſary, Sir,
I'll march to night, and leave my carriages
Behind to follow me. I have made choice
Of Hortenſio, if your Majeſty
Think fit, for my Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He's an honeſt Soul; ſo's Frangypane,
Though ſomewhat tainted with his Poetry;
Take him along, the Wars may cure him,
Or at leaſt wake him from theſe idle dreams,
Off-ſpring of eaſe and love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The War's a Noble School.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: For honeſt Vertuous Souls.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a man of peace, Caliſto; want faith to ward a Bullet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He can make War by's brain: but we looſe time;
I'll give you ſome inſtructions, and diſpatch you:
Spare not the Traytors, though the chief's our Son,
But look on them as Rebels to our Throne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I dare not be diſloyal.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Fortune, I adore thee: theſe tidings came
Juſt in the nick of time: when my dull brains
Were on the rack for ſome neat ſtratagem,
One favourable ſmile of Madam Chance
Set all my deſignes in tune. He remov'd,
My proſpect level to the Princeſs lyes,
No obſtacle between us ſave my birth,
Yet we may mix, for we are both but earth.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Prince like an Egyptian, Duke diſguis'd, Juliana, Clariana.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: HAving now brought you to the Palace-gate,
I muſt commit you to your Deſtiny:
The Army doth expect my ſwift return.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis time you now were with them: they believe
Y'are but retired to your Country-houſe
To ſetch them ſome pecuniary ſupplies.
You muſt continue ſtill the falſe report
Of my being gone to head ſome other Troops
That lie concealed in a place remote,
Expecting a fit opportunity
Upon advantage to diſcloſe themſelves;
For this will raiſe a terrour in the King:
Still keep their wiſeſt Counſels in ſuſpence,
That they 'll be long reſolving what to do:
At worſt, they will not dare employ their force
Againſt our Army in Calabria,
For fear our rumour'd forces here at home
Should ſuddainly the King and Court ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve all your directions,
And make a Politick uſe from time to time
Of theſe blanks by your Princely hand ſubſcrib'd;
On Terraefilius ſpecially, whom I miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Let not your Zeal, my Lord, ſo injure him;
Y' are both my friends; yet Terraefilius
Is of ſo dear concern unto my Soul,
I ſooner ſhould miſtruſt my ſelf then him.
Nature hath molded all his faculties,
As if ſhe intended him fair Vertues Shrine:
And Education hath ſo ſtrengthened
Thoſe Natural Seeds of Honeſty, that
In ſpight of Envy they muſt ever flouriſh.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I wiſh your confidence meet no deceit;
Your Nature is too Noble to miſtruſt:
But if his intimacy with the King
You'd juſtly weigh in Reaſons equal Scale,
And how ſince his endearment the old King's
Ill-grounded Hatred to your ſelf's increaſt,
'Twere worthy a ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Well, I am content to try his Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I wiſh you finde all falſe: however, you'll be
Near enough to dive into his Policy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No more; here comes my Clariana, and
My Siſter: I hope I'm far from knowledge.
Now, my Lord, we muſt but ſigh a parting wiſh,
And ſeparate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Wiſhing your Highneſs ſafety, I am gone:
I hope to meet you next time on your Throne.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Not whilſt my Father lives: for I would prove
Not Heir unto his Kingdome, but his Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am glad howe'er my Brother is eſcap'd,
Since that the King deſign'd him for a Priſon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Such a reſtraint his Spirit could ne'er brook;
His Noble Soul would ſcorn to be confin'd,
And grown intemperate with injuries,
Might have expos'd his body unto ſome
Contagious and Peſtilential Fever,
Or more diſtractive Melancholy kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So may the Wars: thou haſt not nam'd my fear,
Which was the ſecret murther of the Prince;
My credulous Fathers nature being apt
By bloody Villains to be workt upon.
But now my Brother hath a ſpacious field
To juſtifie his innocence, or die
In the Bed of Honour.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Die! dear Madam: that word's deſtructive to us all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He was not born immortal, Clariana:
We all muſt die: Death is to none a ſhame,
But thoſe whoſe vitious lives do merit blame.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I honour thy bravery of ſpirit:
My Clariana's more effeminate,
Fit for loves Dulcet charms; yet is her Soul
With Vertues much enrich'd, though Pity moſt
Within her Breaſt her Excellence may boaſt.

l.hi: Hail, gentle Ladies, you both are
Much leſs fortunate then fair:
I read a ſorrow on your brow,
And by a ſecret knowledge know
The true cauſe of all your woe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What's this? a Soothſayer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One that pretends to Augury it ſeems: I'll try his Art.

sp.speaker: Prince.

l.hi: Sacred Madam, as you ſtand,
This appears a Princeſs hand:

sp.l: Mars and Venus do conjoyn

l.hi: Here within this amorous Line;
By which Art doth make us know,

sp.l: You affect Valerio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A ſtrange knowledge, Clariana!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It amazes me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: By this Triangle, Mars his ſquare,

l.hi: He ſhould now be gone to th' War;
And by this ſame Line of Life,
You may live to be his Wife.
Though he be gone with bloody mind,
He ſhall ne'er your Brother find:
His aim is War, Blood his intent,
Yet in his ſoul he's innocent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Stranger ſtill!

sp.speaker: Prince.

l.hi: In your ear, Madam, by the way,
One thing I have more to ſay:
'Tis in your power to command,

sp.l: And withhold Valerio's hand:

l.hi: Ʋſe your intereſt; do this good,
Save your Lover, and much blood;
Elſe on you will lie the guilt
Of all the blood that's to be ſpilt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Take his counſel, Madam: for ſure his Art's
Divine, and he by th' Gods from Heaven ſent
Our dangers to foretel, our griefs prevent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Moſt learned Sir, let us entreat your ſtay,
That we may yeild juſt Honours to your Art.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Madam, you ſhall command it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You honour us, whilſt we enjoy your skill;
We're careleſs of our fate, and fear no ill.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell thee: ſhe loves thee dearly; dotes on thee almoſt to death.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Dear Caliſto, may I credit this? Livia love me!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thou art the very Idol of her ſoul;
Her Titular Saint. As I was walking
Two hours ſince behind the Mirtle-Grove
Under a Cypreſs Tree, I Livia ſpyed
In ſuch a poſture, as I ſoon did gueſs
Love was the cauſe of her retirement.
Which moved my curioſity to draw
Nearer, where, undiſcern'd, I over-heard
Her thus complain unto her ſelf: Livia,
How hard's thy fate, to be belov'd by one
Unworthy of thy love; and to affect
Luſſurio, dear Luſſurio! With which
Her tears ſo plentifully flowed, they ſtopt
A while her Speech, but taking truce with grief.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: What follow'd then, my dear Caliſto?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: She ſaid, I muſt deviſe ſome way to let him know I love, and how withal I hate Maligno; betwixt whom and me, Nature hath plac'd ſuch an Antipathy, I cannot live till he's deſtroy'd, and by Luſſurio.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I would I had the heart, I'd do it ſtraight, and merit her.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange longing, Sir! but Womens appetites are very exorbitant, eſpecially when they're in love.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: It is her longing moves me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Nay, y'are oblig'd in conſcience, ſince ſhe loves you, and hateth for your ſake Maligno thus.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Nay, I'd do it willingly but for two rubs; the danger, Caliſto, and a certain natural averſion from ſpilling humane blood.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: 'Tis conſiderable: but my life's at your ſervice. Here he comes: obſerve that frown, and neglect not this opportunity to ſee your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! He hath received but a frothy entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How merry the Slave is!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Hath he not cauſe, that triumphs in his Miſtreſſes favours? He hath wearied me with amorous paſſages: were I as you, I would not bear the affront.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Were I confirm'd, you promis'd viſible proof.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Well remembred; make haſte; you'll finde them now together: you ſoon may gueſs what men and women do in private.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If I finde him there, he dies.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Yes, fifty odd years hence. Although theſe Slaves
Want Policy to dive in my deſignes,
Envy may make them vigilant to mark
My actions. Malice many times gives Wit;
I therefore thought it Wiſdome to create
This difference, to keep them ſo employ'd
In countermining of each others love,
That all my actions might paſs unobſerv'd.
But here comes Clariana with the Moor:
I muſt obſcure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now we're in private, I muſt claim your promiſe.

l.hi: Paſt paſſages I'll firſt relate,
And thence the future calculate:
You've lov'd, and been belov'd long ſince,
By this ſame Kingdomes Heir, a Prince.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I'll liſten nearer.

l.hi: Wh • ſe vertues are his crimes; the love
The people bear him, ſome fears move
Within his fathers breaſt: but he
Can't be guilty of diſloyalty.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your ſpeech is Oracle: let me entreat
The Iſſues of our love.

sp.speaker: Prince.

l.hi: By the influence of your Stars,
Nought ſhould threaten it but Wars;
Yet in this Aſcendent-line,

sp.l: Venus doth ſo ſwiftly joyn

l.hi: The God of War, that you may prove
Moſt happy in the Prince his love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Can you not be more poſitive, and tell
Each accident that ſhall befal our loves?

l.hi: 'Tis not in the power of Art,
Such high ſecrets to impart:
For tho' we read within the Skies,
Heavens dark-hidden myſteries,
They're ſo obſcurely there expreſt,
That by moſt they are but gueſt.
If I may judge by what's reveal'd,
And that the Stars have nought conceal'd,
Then this I boldly dare foretel,
Your loves will happy prove, all well.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: A pretty equivocating Prophet.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: May all the Gods ſay, Amen, to your prediction
Could you but tell me where he now reſides,
At your own rate I would the ſecret buy.

l.hi: I cannot by the Stars: for your deſire
Would too much time and ſtudy both require:
Yet am I not ſo unskilful in my Art,
But that in a ſhort ſpace I could impart
A larger knowledge, and by Magick pow'r
Tranſport the Prince i' th' compaſs of an hour
From his conceal'd aboad: but that would wrong
Too much his peace; the other way's too long.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: A ſtrange Promiſer! yet I have heard that
Magick hath rais'd dead men from the Grave.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Beſides my thanks, as an acknowledgement
Of your high learning, and ſo fam'd deſerts,
I do beſeech you wear this Jewel.

l.hi: As Vertues badge upon my breſt,
May fortune make you ever bleſt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: A notable cunning Raskal! he may be uſeful in my deſigne upon the Princes love: ſo the plot is form'd, I'll but confirm my faith by certain queſtions of the particulars of my actions paſt, and ſtraight employ him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Hail, reverend Sir!

p.hi: The Stars protect you, what's your will?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: With what a ſtate he nods! I am inform'd
That by laborious and unwearied ſtudy,
You have obtain'd the ſacred skill
Of Divination, and telling all futurities.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Your information hath not wrong'd you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Might I aſſume the boldneſs to deſire
You would inform me of ſome paſſages
That nearly do concern me, and how therein
I ought my ſelf comport for to avoid
The perils of my fate, I ſhould
Be bountiful in my acknowledgements.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Lend's your hand:

l.hi: If every circle be well ſcann'd
Within the Tablet of your hand,
It doth moſt evidently ſhow,
You to a Prince's bounty owe
All that you are.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: The Devil's in his tongue ſure, or near it, to inform him.

l.hi: You ſeem amaz'd,
But your wonder will be rais'd,
When unto you I do realte
How almoſt from a ſtarving ſtate
You were advanced to this height:
Pray then do your Advancer right;
Plead well his cauſe, to him be juſt,
Or you will ſoon return to duſt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: His knowledge ſtartles me, and more in this
Then all he hath declar'd: theſe ſecrets
Were onely known unto the Prince and me.
H'hath a ſtrange Genius! I muſt make him mine:
If Gold or Promiſes have power to work
Upon his dark-complexion'd face,
I'll him corrupt: none ere reſiſted Gold;
'Twould purchaſe Heaven, were it to be ſold.
I'll finde him out.

sp.speaker: Luſſ.
sp.p: DEnials are all vain, they muſt not paſs for currant; I am too well aſſur'd both of your love to me, and hatred to Maligno.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: The laſt was well gueſt of a blind Prophet: but how I ſhould love you, when, or for what, are all without my memory.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Your Modeſty bars confeſſion, but in your looks I plainly read your heart: do you remember the Mirtle-Grove? Oh Luſſurio, dear Luſſurio!

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Is the Fool mad?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I muſt deviſe ſome way to let him know I love: Do you remember this?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: What ſhould this mean?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Some ſparks of affection, Lady, which not ſtifled would break into a flame. To be plain, your love to me was over-heard; and I being full of pity, loth that ſo fair a creature ſhould pine for me, am come to make a tender of my perſon.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Some Wag hath workt upon his eaſie faith,
Intending to make ſport, which I'll not hinder:
I love wit a life; there is no pleaſure
Comparable to making fools. Ha, ha, ha!
Yonder's Maligno too: I ſpy him peeping:
If I don't play my part, I am no woman. Oh ho!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Did not I tell you this? you muſt conceal
Your love: alas, poor ſoul, ſhe ſwoons. Dear Livia!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: See, ſhe's within his arms: how the Slave hugs her!

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Oh Luſſurio!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Madam, I am here, I am here to ſerve you, love you, any thing you ſhall command.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: If you love me, fight Maligno; he's the man I hate.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Let me receive a warrant from your lips, and through ſeas of blood I'll ſwim to the performance of your will.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, how he ſlavers her! Would my eyes were Baſilisks, to look him dead.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: I hope you'll make a noble uſe of this diſcovery: for had you not o'er-heard my love, it ſhould have quite conſum'd my heart; but ſince ſo unexpectedly you come to know it, diſſimulation's vain. So I commit Maligno to your fury.
sp.stage: Luſſurio ſhakes her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What a letcherous gripe was there! Would this Blade were in thy Guts to cool thee: If wiſhes could deſtroy, or curſes kill, I'd be reveng'd of all my enemies.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Account him dead: he is ſo baſe a Coward, I'll uſe no other VVeapon then my looks.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: God-a-mercy Fear: he dares not look upon a ſword: Ha, ha, ha! what a rare Duel will theſe Herculean ſpirits make! I ſhall gueſs your love by your ſuddain execution.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Thunder deſtroys not quicker then my rage: He comes! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Y'are very pleaſant, Sir: fools laugh at ſhadows.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: If I laugh, I have cauſe: ſo wiſe men laugh at fools. You ſaw Livia here, a pretty Maid, and of a handſome fortune.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And what of her? did ſhe tickle your ſpleen?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Perhaps all men are not of the ſame complexion: I may be worth her ſmiles, whilſt others ſeem toads in her eyes.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I ſeem a Toad?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Baſto, I've ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Enough to conſume thee, Scondrel.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! ſure now they'll draw.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But that I ſcorn to ſtain my ſword in blood So baſe, I'd ſpit thee for this injury.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I wear Steel, Maligno; and in a cauſe like this, VVherein my love to Livia is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thy love to Livia, Slave?

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Yes, and her love to me.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Now they'll fight, or never.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I can no longer: Draw!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: But that you know I lately breath'd a vein,
You durſt as well wade through the Ocean
As breathe that ſound.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Could I but ſpy a looſe ſeam! for if I kill him not out-right, he'll gaſp with ſuch an horrid countenance, it will diſturb my dreams a twelve-month after. I ſay, Defend thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: This is diſhonourable, and baſe, to make a paſs at a naked man.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Draw then! I'm reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I'll ſuck thy ſoul through a Tobacco-pipe, and blow thee with a breath to the Infernal Lake.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How the Rogue quakes! he dares not look upon a ſword, and I dare as well be hang'd as uſe one.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Now Champion, perform bravely my command.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I am engag'd: ſhe will not have the heart to ſee me bleed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How's this? He draws.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I'll make thee a bleeding ſacrifice to this Ladies wrath.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: He has courage too: Love hath conjur'd up his Valour ſure: I am the ſame in love and hatred, a Coward ſtill; but rather then looſe her thus, I'll wink; for fighting ſo, I ſhall not ſee my danger.
Come on!
sp.stage: Being both ready to make a paſs, Muſick ſounds for the Kings entrance.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Sa, ſa.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Make way for the King; bear back there.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: 'Void the Room; the King's a coming.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Any excuſe ſerves Cowards: this Jeſt ſhall to the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: YOu are all dull and negligent, or elſe
It were impoſſible a Traytor ſhould
Lie thus conceal'd within our Territories.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Upon my life 'tis but an idle fear,
A vain report ſpread by the Enemy,
To diſcompoſe your Council, and ſuſpend
The execution of your juſt revenge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It cannot be: by Letters from the Camp
VVe have receiv'd aſſur'd intelligence
Our Son's not there, and that the Duke commands
As General.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The laſt may be: but that your ſon's not there,
My faith cannot digeſt: It is too groſs.
Pleaſe but your Majeſty a little weigh
In Reaſon's balance ev'ry circumſtance,
You'll ſoon perceive th' impoſſibility
Of the Princes lying hid, at the leaſt
VVith any power, either capable
To diſturb your peace, or awake your fears.
