An Army's not cover'd with a Buſhel,
Nor circumſcrib'd i' th' compaſs of a Cave:
Might I be worthy to adviſe you, Sir,
Your Army ſhould all march: for that ſmall part
The General did take with him along,
At beſt can onely keep your Foes in play,
Not conquer them. 'Tis good, Sir, to make ſure:
Whilſt Treaſon breathes, no Prince can be ſecure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We will conſider on't.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Let me offer one conſideration more.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: This Magician can reſolve me whether my love ſhall be ſucceſsful. See! Maligno's at it: May Saturn and Diana have been in Conjunction at thy Nativity, and juſt in Oppoſition to Venus, to croſs thy affections.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Saturn doth ſo much command

l.hi: Within the tablet of your hand,
And croſſes every Planet ſo,
You ſhould be Knaeve and Coward too.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! his nature to an inch.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis rather thine: the Devil always lyes.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: If that Rule hold, you ſhould be Satans Ape.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Sfoot, a rare Fellow! how he jeers him! Prethee wilt tell my fortune, and whether I ſhall thrive in Livia's love?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Good dark-complexion'd Sir, ſatisfie his curioſity: He hath a great fancy to marriage, that goes to the Devil for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Prince.

l.hi: Lend me your Paw, I muſt be juſt;
You are too much inclin'd to Luſt;
Envious, Malicious, Coward, want
No Vice becomes a Sycophant:

sp.l: Livia's not to be thy Wife,

l.hi: Ʋntil thou doſt amend thy Life.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: The Devil's turn'd Friar, I think, and gives inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Doth truth gaul you? Ha, ha! his nature to an inch.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is he ſo great a Maſter in his Art?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your Majeſty would wonder at his skill:
His conſtant ſtudy, and deep-diving Brain,
Have plung'd into the ſubtleties of Art,
And ſearch'd the bottom of Aſtronomy;
By which his knowledge is ſo far improv'd,
That by a ſpeculation in the Stars,
And other Planets that do govern us,
He's able to foretel our fate; and as
A proof of his undoubted skill, although
A ſtranger to this State and us, he can
Unfold the ſecret actions of our life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We'll finde a time to talk with him about Our near concerns.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Shall I preſent him to your Majeſty?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not now; we're indiſpos'd: bring him In private to us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I ſhall, my Liege: Pleaſe you to honour him With your hand in paſſing by.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Preſent him to us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I've given you a high character to the King, Who is diſpos'd to honour you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Y'are moſt obliging.
sp.stage: He preſents him to kiſs his hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your worth is known to us already, Sir:
We ſhortly ſhall conſult your beſt advice
Concerning ſome paſſages of our life.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Your Majeſties commands will honour me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Bring him ſome two hours hence unto our Cabinet. Maligno! Luſſurio!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: So, we are call'd upon again; a good Omen we are not out of favour.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Since 'tis ſo well, let's ſhake hands, Brother, and plot together whilſt we enjoy the Kings ſmiles, againſt Caliſto: The Upſtart is falſe-hearted.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Tho' we are not perfect friends, we'll joyn againſt the common enemy.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Content. We'll wrangle like City-Atturneys at
Loves Bar, and joyn like Brothers in Caliſto's ruine.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: And if your Art with th' Princeſs doth prevail,
As ſhe is ſuperſtitious enough
For to be wrought (and with much eaſe) into
A firm belief the Gods decree her mine,
I'll make thee richer then thou'lt wiſh thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You ſhall command my Art. But, Sir, me thinks
If you had made the motion firſt, and try'd
Her pulſe, how to your Perſon ſhe's inclin'd,
It had not been improper.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I have; but finde her more averſe unto
My ends then Anchorites to Luſt: ſhe vow'd
That I appear'd more loathſome to her eyes
Then a ſwoln Toad, that betwixt things in Nature
Moſt oppos'd, there could not be found the like
Antipathy. By Courtſhip I deſpair
T' obtain her love, unleſs that mine be gilt
With ſome feign'd Piety, as a command
Fro' th' Gods, or by affirming that
This Match will work a Peace betwixt her Brother
And the King: for ſhe'll ſwallow any thing
From you, though never ſo ridiculous;
Her faith is ſo confirmed by your Art.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Sir, this appears too circular a courſe;
You wheel too much about: would you give way,
And free me by your Power from the Law,
By Magick Art I could compound a charm,
Which ſoon as taſted ſhould procure love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Could'ſt thou do this, thou wouldſt enſlave me to thee.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Relie on me: within this hour call for't.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Perform, and I will have thee Deified,
Then worſhip thee my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Confide in me. — Ungrateful Villain!
Since thou haſt thus deceiv'd my truſt, I will
Deſpair to finde an honeſt man. Through the
Small Pilgrimage of my life I ve made ſearch,
And before this could never meet a man
Whom I could think worthy to ſhare my heart:
This I have truſted with my ſecret ſins,
Try'd with all baits that might corrupt a Knave,
As Honour, Riches, Opportunity,
And ſtill I found him honeſt; no Ambition,
No Deceit, no Falſhood, no Flattery
Could I ere perceive: Yet I watch'd him neer,
And on a ſuddain to have his heart beget
So proud a thought as marrying my ſiſter,
Appears a miracle in Nature: ſure
The Court ſpreads a corruption through each ſoul
Sucks in that poys'nous Air: But in this ſhape
I'll dive into his ſoul, and thence extract
Each helliſh thought his brain doth hammer out:
For I do calculate by his diſcourſe,
Some dark Deſignes lie hid within his breaſt.
I'll play the Midwife, give his Projects birth,
Which I'll tranſmute to Air, but him to Earth.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Piſtols diſcbarg'd within. Enter Frangypane driving balf a ſcore before him,— Valerio, Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: SLaves, my Livia ſtraight reſtore,
Or I will ſwim in bloody gore
Unto her reſcue.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Arm, Arm!

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Arm, Arm!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Give to the Dukes Tent an alarm.
I'll cut my way unto the place
Where you in bondage and diſgrace
My Livia keep: I'll ſet her free:
My Sword ſhall give her Liberty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What hath the Mad-man done! h'as loſt himſelf,
sp.stage: Enter Valerio, Hortenſio, with their ſwords drawn.
sp.l: And deſperately engag'd our ruine too:
This comes of fooliſh Jeſts: we muſt make ſport
With Mad-men! A Plague upon the brain that
Did contrive the Letter.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: None would have thought him ſuch a Mad-man, as to engage his perſonal Valour amongſt thouſands, upon a bare ſuggeſtion that his Miſtreſs was taken Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To what folly will not love engage men!
But let him periſh, and the fool die with him,
So we are ſafe. Should th' enemy but know▪
How ſmall a ſtrength we are, alarmed by
This fool, their rouzed Valours might purſue us
T' our very Tents, and there devour us
Before the body of our Army come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your Excellence ſaith true: one deſperate ſool
May more injure a well-order'd Camp, then
Then Valours of a thouſand can repair.
Yet it is pity he ſhould periſh thus:
The Alarm ſtill continues: I believe
He is not yet deſtroy'd; would your Excellence
Give way, I would endeavour with a Troop—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We may'nt engage ſo many lives upon
So deſperate a deſigne. Go rally up
Our Troops, and let them take th' advantage of
The field. Draw them up in ſuch a figure
As may beſt offend their enemies, and
Defend themſelves. The Duke perhaps ſeeing
Our willingneſs to take the field, will judge
Us Maſters of more ſtrength i' th' Town.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Your Orders ſhall be punctually obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For publick ſafety having taken care,
I may bemoan my Couſins ſevere fate,
Whoſe ſoul though tainted much with Poeſie,
And more enſlav'd to love, was of a ſtrain
Noble, and valiant like his Anceſtors:
So many Vertues did adorn his mind,
As for one folly may well plead's excuſe.
All Great men, are not States-men; and if he
Did want ſome judgement to controul his wit,
Envy her ſelf will ſay his bloody fate
Did buy our Paſtime at too dear a rate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: DId none ſecond him?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: None.
His ſingle courage did diſarm our Guards;
Which having put to flight more by ſurprize
Then a judicious Valour, he boldly
Fronted our whole Army, and bad reſtore
His Livia: whereat we ſtood amaz'd,
Whilſt he (as if ſome Fury had poſſeſt
His Arm) broke through our Troops, where like
A God of War he cut his way:
For all our faculties were ſo employ'd
In admiration of the bold attempt,
We let our ſelves be ſlain; until a Fellow
Of a duller ſoul, and quite uncapable
Of admiration, ſhot him through the head.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Twas pity ſo much Valour ſhould be wed▪
To ſo much indiſcretion: did he die
Immediately upon the Wound?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: No, my Lord:
Having with ſighs bemoan'd his Miſtreſs fate,
Condemn'd his Courage, and his Fortune curs'd
For ſetting of this period to his life
Before he had his Livia enlarg'd,
He did begin to faint, and thereupon
Two of our skilfull'ſt Chyrurgeons were call'd
To ſound the Wound: which they ſo mortal found,
And him with loſs of blood ſo faint, they judg'd
Him dead, as in effect he was, when on
A ſuddain, as if another ſoul were
Shot into's breaſt, his cheeks began to wear
The Livery of Life, and by their ſcarlet
Tincture did proclaim that his remaining blood
Did yet ſuſtain his Vital parts.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: When Nature was ſo ſtrong, could not their Art Preſerve him?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: It was impoſſible: for all our hopes
Were but meer lightnings before his death.
As you have ſeen a poor departing ſnuff
A while burn dim, and on a ſuddain blaze,
Then droop again, then blaze, and quite go out:
So he would ſeem almoſt reviv'd, and vent
Poetick Raptures of ſo high a ſtrain,
As all did judge him in Elizium then.
In fine, he di'd our wonder and our grief.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Poor Gentleman! I much condole his fate;
He doth deſerve our pity, not our hate.
See that his Obſequies be well perform'd,
Agreeable unto his Noble Birth.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I ſhall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And that ſevereſt Diſcipline be kept
Throughout the Camp; unleſs the Foe aſſault,
Let none preſume by any Hoſtile act
T' exaſperate the Enemy: until
I do receive inſtructions from the Prince,
I would not willingly engage: for they
Who venture all, ſhould with much caution play.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: TIs in your power to oblige me, Sir,
And build your ſelf a fortune: I ſhall leſs
Doubt your performance of our will, becauſe
Your intereſt is link'd with mine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Were there no other motive then the Truſt
You do impoſe upon my faith, it were
A bond inviolable: but ye are my Lord,
Patron, indeed the Baſis of my fate.
Judge not my heart, Sir: By this ſable Busk,
I wear my blackeſt Livery in ſight;
Within, my ſoul's all innocent and white.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I am confirm'd: make but the Princeſs mine,
And to thy Art I will erect a Shrine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I'm your creature: the whirlpool of his heart
Is bottomleſs; I cannot ſound the depth;
Yet I perceive a maſs of confus'd ills
Lie there upon a heap, expecting a
Fit time to take their ſhapes: ſome deep deſigne
In Embryon lies, as yet unripe for birth:
But he's ſo Politick, that by no means
Can I obtain the knowledge; yet ſometimes
(As my diſtruſt makes me obſerve him ſtill)
He'll ſpeak ſuſpitiouſly, as if he were
Ambitious of a Crown, and did aſpire
Beyond my Siſters love, as if he meant
To raiſe his fortune upon my deſcent.
It muſt be ſo: but I'm reſolv'd to try
How far the bargain's drove 'twixt him and Hell;
For he's much Devil ſince he came to Court.
But here's my ſiſter, ſhe muſt firſt be try'd,
And ſo muſt Clariana too: 'Tis juſt
Being once deceiv'd, that I ſhould all diſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I did long ſince ſuſpect my Brothers love
By 's frequent Viſits to the Duke, and am
Much pleas'd in the diſcerning choice he made
In you: for believe me, Clariana,
I am proud to call your Beauty Siſter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your expreſſions, Madam, rather teach me
What to deſire, then ſhew me what I am,
Ever a ſervant unto your Excellence.
The ſtile of Siſter is an Epithet
My humble birth and fortune dare not hope;
And yet to doubt it, ſuch a Treaſon were
To th' Princes vertue and integrity,
I ſhould deſerve to periſh through deſpair;
And whilſt I doubt his love, by 's hatred die.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your love's too hard a Riddle to finde out:
You dare not hope, and yet you dare not doubt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I dare not doubt his love, nor build my hope
Upon the merit of my own deſerts;
Yet my demerit by his bounty may
Be elevated to a height: his love's
Capable to create within my ſoul
All thoſe Seraphick Vertues which the Gods
Enrich the ſouls of Monarchs with. My grief's,
The world ſhould think my loves to's Title's linkt,
When 'tis his Vertue onely charms my ſoul:
His Star-like Minde's the thing I doat upon,
And ſuperſtitiouſly adore.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: With what a Zeal ſhe doth unvail her heart!
Though I forſwore hereafter to confide
In any Mortal, I can't her diſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Grieve not your ſelf: the world will ſoon diſcern:
Your love's unfeign'd, by your ſo deep concern.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You too much honour me in your belief
Of my unfeigned love; and as for thoſe
Whoſe ſelf-deceit doth teach them to miſtruſt,
I ſhall convince them by my tears; and if
The Prince (the Gods avert ſo great an ill!)
Should meet with a ſiniſter fate, my death
Shall regiſter to all ſucceeding time,
A Woman once did love, and faithfully!

lg.l: That Miracle would ſcarcely gain belief:
Yet if any o' the Sex e'er guilty were
Of Conſtancie, this Lady muſt be ſhe.
In gen'ral Rules there ſome exceptions be:
But I'll accoſt them.

l.hi: Ladies, I wiſh the Stars may ſtill
Be propitious to your Will.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your wiſhes do deſerve our thanks.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Madam, laying my Oracles aſide,
I have a Meſſage to you from a friend
That loves you more then life: for with his ſoul
He'd purchaſe your affection.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What ſhould this mean? he ſpeaks no canting Language. Proceed, Sir, to his Name.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: That ſecret muſt not be communicated
To any but your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This Lady ſhares my counſels: be bold, and name him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: But firſt, I muſt entreat you to reſolve
Theſe two Queries, Whether your heart be ſtill
Your own, or prediſpos'd unto ſome ſecret Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your queſtion's ſomewhat ſawcy: to the next.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Pardon, Madam, if I deliver in
Too blunt a phraſe my Embaſſie: I was
Not bred an Orator: but I'll proceed.
If in the Book of Fate it were decreed
That you muſt marry the Ungrateful'ſt Knave,
The Bloodieſt Villain, and moſt Devil-man,
Or ſee the total ruine of your State,
Your Brothers Martyrdom, your Fathers death,
With the deſtruction of your Family,
Which would you firſt embrace? that Monſter Man,
Or the immediate ruine of your Race?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I had rather hazard all, a thouſand ills
Beſides thoſe you have nam'd, then in a thought
Be guilty of ſuch crimes: the greateſt good
That's purchas'd with a ſin, is too dear bought.
But I ſuppoſe, Sir, that your Queries were
A meer device to dive into my thoughts:
Your Art is built on cunning more then truth.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Upon my Life theſe dangers menace both
The State and your whole Family, unleſs
You marry this ſame man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! he hath a Name.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Do not deride my Art, unleſs that I
Employ my utmoſt power to oppoſe
Caliſto's fortune: Madam, that's his Name:
Theſe evils will enſue.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Still more ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Was't he we laught at in the Gallery?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, that formal Coxcomb, that would needs make love to us, hath ſee'd this Fellow for his Advocate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh do not injure him, his knowing ſoul
May hold a ſtrict intelligence with fate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The Gods are too juſt t' impoſe ſuch cruelties.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: My Miſtreſs is of a more eaſie faith;
But 'tis her Zeal to Vertue: Superſtition
Is Religions Fool. Madam, you would
Not be ſo obſtinate, ſhould the Kingdomes
Safety depend upon your love, to ſcruple
Change.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The world ſhould rather periſh then I
Redeem it by Inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Y' are generous both, Ladies of noble ſouls;
I admire you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Whither will this man?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Since I have found you both ſuch great examples
In Vertues, generous beyond your Sex,
I'll put my life into your hands. Know, that
By th' Prince your Brother I am here employ'd
To propagate his Intereſt in this Court:
For doubting of Caliſto's faith, (as he
Hath cauſe: for it is evident that falſe
Favourite endeavours on your love, and
On your Brothers ruine, to build himſelf
A fortune) he ſent me hither to dive
Into his ſoul, which I have done with all
The policy I could, yet cannot ſound
Its depth. Would but your Highneſs feign a kinde
Concurrence with his love, (thereby heightned
In his hopes) he would explain himſelf.
Proſperity makes men bold; but joyn'd with love,
All thoughts of danger it will quite remove:
Drunk with ambition, he'll his thoughts diſcloſe;
Graſp at the ſhadow, and the ſubſtance loſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would do much to ſerve my Brother, but
I'm yet unſatisfi'd of your commiſſion:
You may prove ſome great Impoſtor, perhaps,
One of Caliſto's creatures, hither come
To teach me firſt to feign, and then conſent:
But I'll diſtruſt, and then I ſha'nt repent.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: This Ring is my Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Y'are my Lord the Prince.
sp.stage: She runs to him, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Madam, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Do not diſguiſe your ſelf: y'are either he,
Or elſe his Murtherer: for with that Ring
He ſwore he'd never part whilſt he had life.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nor will he, Clariana.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My deareſt Lord!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My Princely Brother!

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I could divide my ſelf between you two:
You ſhare my heart and love. But ſee where comes
That curſt Caliſto to prevent our joys.
Dear Siſter, for my ſake aſſume the ſhape
Of Love: flatter his credulous ears with
Sugred hopes, till from the very centre
Of his heart each ſecret we extract,
And puniſh him according to his fact.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'll do my beſt to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Dear Clariana, I muſt wiſh a kiſs,
And take my leave.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Gods protect you ever.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: The Ladies ſmile upon you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How can they chuſe, when I prefer your love?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Why? Was it well receiv'd?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: At firſt (like a ſtrong ſhip that makes the waves
Rebound, and ſhew their angry foam about
Her Ribs) ſhe did repulſe your love; whereat
I ſeem'd a little to draw off, that with
A double force I might return to ſtorm
Her reſolution, as at laſt I did:
Leaving Loves ſofter Theam, to which her heart
Seem'd an Antagoniſt, I had recourſe
To what deceives the World, Hypocriſie;
Which I did cloath in ſuch a pious Garb,
Religion might have ſmil'd t' have ſeen her ſelf
So Ap'd: With pious tears I did bemoan
Her Fate, yet on my knees at the ſame time
Intreat her to embrace 't, aſſuring her
With a thouſand imprecations, ſtrengthen'd
By twice as many oaths, that ſhe'd be cauſe
(In her withſtanding of her Deſtiny)
Of the whole ruine of her Fathers ſtate,
Her Brothers life, incur the Peoples hate.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Excellent Hypocrite! That we two might
Incorporate, and overthrow the World
With Policy! Was not the Princeſs mov'd?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Beyond expreſſion: ſtartled in her thoughts,
Her Hate and Piety were ſo intermixt,
As barr'd all reſolution: You ſhe ſeem'd
To hate with all the malice of a Woman;
Contemning your Alliance with a ſcorn
Might equal Cleopatra's, when Caeſar thought
T' have led her a baſe Captive unto Rome,
T' adorn his Triumphs: Yet Religion,
Mixt with a zealous fear t' offend the Gods,
Made her more apt to liſten to my words,
Which her ears faſter drunk then her confus'd
And much perplex'd Imagination could
Digeſt, or indeed duely weigh. To tell
You all her Doubts, and how I did reſolve them,
Too tedious were; ſuffice it that at laſt
She was convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But by what happy means?
Let me know every circumſtance, that
I may adore the brain which did contrive it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: When nothing could prevail, and I perceiv'd
She was inclin'd with Conſcience to diſpence,
And hazard all I threatned, I took a
Pen, and ſtraight drew a Scheme before her Eyes;
Whereby I ſeem'd to calculate your Birth,
And ſoon convinced her too credulous faith,
You were a Prince led hither by the Stars,
For the accompliſhment o' th' Gods Decrees;
Whereat ſhe ſeem'd tranſported in her ſoul,
And crediting my words, began to love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Y'ave render'd me too happy: were my life
Conſum'd i' th' ſatisfaction of this ſervice,
I ſhould ſtill die ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This ſervice, Sir, will ſcarce deſerve your thanks;
Try me in ſomething may be worth your love.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: After this ſervice paſt, what canſt thou do
May equally oblige me?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Sir, I can bring the Prince, the onely man
That ſtands between you and your proudeſt hopes,
Into your power: the old King I look on
As a meer ſhadow: I know your intereſt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The Devil hath inſpir'd him with my own thoughts,
Thou talk'ſt of bleſſings rather to be wiſht
Then hop'd for, or effected.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Be not incredulous: my Art improv'd
By my great Zeal to ſerve you, will make me
Work greater Miracles.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your courteſies confound me: I muſt crave
Some time to prize them as I ought: but if
I thrive in my ambitious hopes, you muſt
Divide the Empire.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Is your ambition there? Y'are ſomewhat wide:
If all hit right, 'tis you that muſt divide,
But not my Crown: They that by crimes aſpire,
Should be cut ſhort, that they may grow no higher.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo. Come, Sir, let's to the King,
'Tis much about the time he did appoint.
The Princes death we will contrive by th' way:
Danger doth threaten evils at a ſtay.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: DEar Frangypane, how noble was thy love
To die for me! what generous ſparks lie hid
And ſmother'd in extravagant Fancies?
Thy Noble death hath gain'd more then thy life
Could ever purchaſe thee, my Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prethee liſten; for the Wench is run
Diſtracted ſure, ſince Frangypane's death,
And ſo tranſported, that a Lord did die
For love of her: ſhe's quite Platonick grown,
And doats upon his Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How Love doth play with Mortals!

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Holy Soul, that graceſt th' Elizium ſhades
With thy bleſt company, and rendreſt us
Unhappy by thy abſence, hear my Vow:
My Heart hereafter ſhall be ever thine,
And free from all Terreſtrial Love, aſpire
By thy example to become Divine,
And flee towards thee, becauſe it can no higher.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How ſhe's exalted!

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: No Mortals touch ſhall ere pollute my lip,
Nor luſtful gripe provoke a wanton ſmile,
Nor amorous fingers be allow'd to skip
Into my Boſom, leſt they ſhould beguile
Thee of my love, and me of that ſame part
I'd wholly dedicate to thee, my heart.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: She's high-flown in love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A true Platonick, a very Spirit in Fleſh.

sp.speaker: Livia.

l.hi: To love's a trifle: but to love like me,
Would poſe Loves Deity.
She beſt on earth's eſteem'd to love,
Doth conſtant'ſt to her object prove;
But I much higher move,
Loving an Object though it abſent be:
In this who equals me?
But what talk I here of Equality?
As if each common man

sp.l: Might vie with Frangypane.

l.hi: Had other Lovers but a Saint like mine,
So worthy and divine,
Their Offering too would be as high
As mine unto his Sanity:
With what good juſtice can
I tax a want of love in others then;
Or my own Vertues raiſe,
From what is onely due unto his praiſe?
I lov'd not's earth; nor is it I
Now love bis immortality,
But he that elevates my Soul ſo high.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sure ſhe's inſpired.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: With her deceas'd Lovers Genius.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: He ſpoke Raptures, and ſhe ſings them: but here Her living Lovers come; ſhall's make ſome ſport?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
'Twere pleaſant ſure to ſee them fight; they'll ſnarl (they ſay) like Dogs at a Country-wicket, and draw their
ſwords, but 'tis to wound the Air: for if one makes a paſs, the other retires. Livia made me the prettieff relation!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: They look indeed as if they were of the Peace.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: To ſet a period to our fatal War,
Which might produce the ſhedding of much blood,
I am content.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And ſo am I: Him that ſhe chuſes, happy be his lot.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Livia, here are thoſe will diſturb your meditations.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Wench is in beaven ſure already;
Her thoughts are with Frangypane.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you begin.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: The Princeſs is here; ſhe'll laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll warrant you ſome mirth: Luſſurio!

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: An' pleaſe your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Y'are a diligent ſervant, we love you well; and having heard the love you bear our Maid of Honour, reſolve to recompence your merit, by making it a Match. She is an Heireſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Your Highneſs bounty ſo confounds me, I can't expreſs my thanks: my very Soul's your ſlave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your modeſty deſerves our favour: Go, ſend that Fellow to us; I hear he is a Pretender: We can diſtinguiſh merit.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Madam: I'll be as obſervant as your Puppy-Dog.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mark then my beck, when thus I hold my finger.
Ceaſe, Livia: carry her to my Chappel,
Where you ſhall find a Prieſt in readineſs.
To marry you.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.p: Madam —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No more: call him to us.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What means your Highneſs?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
To have this Fellow beaten. Livia's in her dumps; ſhe'll ſcratch his eyes out: and how Maligne will comport
himſelf, is worth our expectation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Luſſurio, Madam, made me believe you'd ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They ſay y'are a Coward.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your Highneſs may ſay your pleaſure: but if there be any mortal fleſh that dare traduce me, the ſwallowing of my ſword, though he digeſted it, ſhould not expiate the injury.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'm glad you talk ſo valiantly; I ever had you in my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to favour your poor Vaſſal.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Could I but ſee one ſingle proof of Valour,
One fighting Action to convince my faith,
My Livia ſhould be yours: I love her well,
And would beſtow her on a deſerving Perſon,
Such I hope you are.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Oh that I had an opportunity!
My Valour like a flaſh of Lightning
Should quite conſume my bold Antagoniſt.
sp.stage: The Princeſs gives the ſigne, Luſſurio goes to ſnatch up Livia, who cuffs him: he runs away: Maligno coming to her reſcue, ſhe ſnatches out his ſword.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now ſhew your Valour.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Muſt you both affront me? though thy Companion's fled, I'll be reveng'd on thee?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh good Madam! I came to reſcue you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: To abuſe me, to diſturb my peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Good Lady, ſuppreſs your fury: ask the Princeſs, I meant no harm.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He's ſufficiently frighted; I'll be his bail.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: For your ſake I'll pardon him: his ſword
I'll offer up at the Sepulchre of
My dead Lord for a Trophey.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: In memory of the conqueſt y' have obtain'd
Upon Maligno's hot affection.
Poor Wench! Time may recover her:
How prettily we entertain griefs!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The time had elſe ſeem'd long before the Prince
Return'd for the Kings Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hope in that diſguiſe he'll work his peace.
But here he comes; with him, Luſſurio:
He appears troubled, we had beſt withdraw:
I'll news will reach our ears too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I fear ſo too: My panick thoughts of late
Hold ſtrict intelligence with the Princes fate.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: IT is but this, when I do ſpeak the word,
Do you appear, and like a ſtatue ſtand
Before us, till I waft my Wand, and then
Make your Exit.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Muſt it be needs in Armour? I do not love that dreadful poſture: If there be a Looking-glaſs in the Room, I ſhall be afraid of my ſelf: I had rather appear like a Fury.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No other ſhape can pleaſure my deſigne,
Which is, to tell you true, (you hate Caliſto,
And therefore with more confidence I truſt you)
To put an abuſe upon him.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Could this be done, I were too happy: for
Baſe Maligno, contrary to his Oath,
Hath quite forſaken me, and cleaves unto
His party, in hopes of gaining Livia.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: In that deſign I'll likewiſe croſs his ends;
For I'll compound a potion by my art,
Which if but taſted by your Miſtriſs once;
She'll doat on you with ſuch a vehement love,
Her life will ſolely in your power be:
Then you ſhall ſee Caliſto ſo much fool'd.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Let him be hang'd; I care not what he be:
Make but fair Livia mine, I'll worſhip night
In honour of your dark complexion.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Think her your own. Here comes Caliſto with
Your Rival, I'll make them howl anon:
You know both time and place.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: I do: I'll immediately make my ſelf drunk,
To appear valiant in my martial Acoutrements.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Tell her y' are ſent by th' King with new Orders
To the General: I know ſhe'll ſend a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: That's not to be doubted, for ſhe extreamly loves him: but how can it advance my love?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: For that rely on me: do but this kindneſs,
And if I make not Livia thine,
I'll be thy bond-ſlave ever.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You are my confidence.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But when you have obtain'd the Letter, let me
See you before you begin your Journey.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I ſhall: Livia will ſufficiently recompence all ſervices.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Confide in me. This Plot was well deſign'd:
For I ſhall court my Rival to his Grave;
And on the Pyram de of all his Joy,
By his own Kiſſes I ſhall him deſtroy.
But ſee where the Magician walks! His anſwers
To the King were ſo ambiguous, that
They breed diſtruſt: But I'll his promiſe urge
To let me ſee the Prince, from whom juſt now
This Letter I receiv'd: but firſt I'll ſee
If he can tell the place of his abode

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What's that he mutters to himſelf? his looks
Speak him diſpleas'd; the contents of that Letter
Might be worth my knowledge: but 'tis intomb'd.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You were very myſtick in all you told
The King; your ſence is ſo ambiguous,
'Twill time require to unriddle it:
The King is no way ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No matter, ſir; I ſtudy not his favour:
His ſtars ſo threaten him, I dare not build
My Intereſt on his unſtable fate:
On you my fortunes ſolely do depend;
Y' are Heavens Favourite, the Minion of
The Stars:
There's not a Planet threatens your deſigns.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Be a true Prophet to me, and thou ſhalt
Be canoniz'd, and have Altars conſecrated
To thy name. But I've receiv'd unlucky news.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: From the Prince?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Thou art an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Never fear 't: come at th'appointed hour
To my Apartment, you ſhall ſee his figure,
Which ſhall at large diſcover all his plots.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You promis'd me the ſubſtance; to tranſport
His perſon hither.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Had he been vitious, Sir, it might been done;
But he's ſo good, the holy Spirits have
Him in protection, and preſerve him from
The force of Magick Charms: But this ſame ſpirit
Which I intend to raiſe, ſhall both reſemble
The Prince in ſhape and minde, and ſo declare
Thoſe ſecrets that may ruine him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It is enough: I ſhall not fail my time;
Nor your Juſt Reward.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Your are too Munificent.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My heart was ne'er ungrateful: It is fit
That to your charms I uſe a Counter-ſpell.
You know too much of me and my deſignes
To live: befides, it is not ſafe to truſt
A man with life, who retains the ſame power
To unthrone me, as to inſtal me King.
'Tis a receiv'd Maxime amongſt ſome,
To deſtroy thoſe who have obliged them
Beyond their power to remunerate.
Sure 'tis a kind of gratitude, when Earth
Cannot reward their ſervice, to ſend them
To Heaven for a recompence.
This Man can't fadge amiſs: for he is well
Known to the Devil, ſhould he go to Hell.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: MY Cenius triumphs in the rare events
Of my ſucceſs: Fortune's th' onely Goddeſs 'Twas ſhe
I adore; and well ſhe merits it.
That from a Mendicant created me
The boſome-friend and counſel of a Prince;
Whom I did follow but to ſerve my ſelf,
Or rather he ſerv'd me: for my full will,
Like to a raging ſtream, bore all before it:
My counſel was his Guide, and I the Minion
Of his Soul. From this ſo happy eſtate,
Fortune advanc'd me to a great Kings ear;
Whence I did ſuck advantage to my ſelf,
Leaving a poiſon to infect the State.
Fortune's in fine aſſiſtant to my Riſe,
The Princes death is plotted in this Brain:
His Siſters Love entitles me the Heir
Unto this Kingdome: yet to make all ſure,
I have diſpatcht Maligno to the Camp,
With Letters ſo exquiſitely poyſon'd
By a Mountebank, Valerio dies in reading
Their contents, and I live unſuſpected.
The Princeſs lines muſt cut his line of Life;
To him they'll give a Grave, to me a Wife.
But here comes my Familiar! how he works
For my advantage! I will ſtand aſide.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I hope your Letters will ſo far prevail
Upon Valerio, that he'll ſtraight unite
His forces with the Duke, and both return
T' inform the King how much he is abus'd
By Caliſto, and other Sycophants.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let not your fancy nouriſh the leaſt doubt:
Valerio's heart is ſo at my command,
I ſteer it as I pleaſe: continue you
Your wonted practice to amuſe the Court,
And ſo avoid ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You are my dear Inſtructreſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yonder's Caliſto: his jealous thoughts will put
A bad conſtruction on your Complements.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis true; I ſaw him not: Siſter, your feign'd
Kindneſs muſt make amends for all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will endeavour to play the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Brave active Slave! what way he makes for my Addreſs! I'll advance towards them: As I live, ſhe ſmiles upon me. He that neglects ſo fair a ſummons, deſerves to periſh in his hopes; and from the higheſt Pinacle of Fortune, fall to Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: He advances: Now play your part.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Being emboldened, Madam, by your ſmiles,
I come to make a tender of my love,
To ſacrifice unto thoſe eyes, a heart
That bears no other figure then your form,
Nor craves no other Miſtreſs then your ſelf.
Accept it, Madam; and with it receive
All faith, all love, ſervice and conſtancy
Your hopes can fancie, or your ſelf deſire.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So rich a gift no Princeſs ſhould refuſe▪
Nor ſhall you finde me obſtinate: for when
I am confirm'd your love is ſuch as you
Deliver it, 'twill be no miracle
To gain upon me an exchange of hearts:
Till when, I ſhall ſuſpend my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You are a Mine of Goodneſs; and when my ſtars
Shall make me happy by enjoying you,
My faculties ſhall wholly be employ'd
In your advancement. No Kingdom ſhall lie
Within the proſpect of your ſight, which you
Can wiſh, and not command: This pow'rful Arm
(Strengthened by the Magick of your ſmiles)
Shall make our Neighb' ring perty Princes know,
At Juliana's Will they all muſt bow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I doubt not, Sir, your Generoſity;
But I am not ambitious: My thoughts
Ne'er coveted anothers right: This Throne
May ſatisfie both me and you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She's gone: but her laſt words are deeply here
Engrav'd. This Throne may ſatisfie both me
And you! Oh ſilver-ſounding words! beyond
The Muſick of the Sphears! A harmony
Beyond the Divine Notes of Orpheus!
He mov'd the ſavage Beaſts and Trees to dance;
But her ſweet Accents might inſpire them with
Diſcourſive Souls, teach them Ambition firſt,
And then to ſway the Earth. Me thinks I ſee
My ſelf upon a Throne, and th' admiring
Multitude envying at my fortune,
Yet doing homage to the thing they curſe.
If in Idea 'tis ſo brave a thing
To Rule and Govern like a God on earth,
What Heaven then muſt the fruition be!
But I ſhall looſe my ſelf in idle dreams:
There's one ſtroak more before I reach this pitch;
My Title muſt be dipt i' th' Prince his Blood:
Onely his death makes my Pretention good.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Hortenſio, Maligno, Officers, Valerio, brought in a chair, Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: THe General's poyſon'd: it muſt be ſo:
Suddain Diſtempers that are natured;
Cannot produce in two minutes ſpace ſuch
Grievous ſymptomes.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You ſpeak as if you did ſuſpect the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I broyl alive; Wildfire's in my ſcull;
I burn, I burn: Give me a Sea of Ice,
Chryſtal diſſolved, A Diſh of Virgins Tears
To quench the flames I feel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Dear General, how did the evil ſeize you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not: ſure it is ſome puniſhment
Inflicted by the Gods for Idolizing
Of theſe Lines, theſe ſo Divine Characters,
Which I no ſooner did approach my Lips,
But my ſoul met them, and did thence convey
Into my ſoull this torment worſe then Hell.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let the Paper be examin'd, Sir;
It may contain ſome Hell-bred poiſon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, it can't; it from the Princeſs came:
Do not prophane that ſacred innocence.
Let me alone! why do you make me live
To adde unto my torments? I'll ſpeak no more:
Pray let me bury all my griefs in ſilence.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sir, here's the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Death is the beſt Phyſitian: Let me ſleep:
A quiet Grave to eaſe me of this pain,
Were Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.l: Take comfort, Sir: I have an Antidote
Which doth by a Specifick Quality
Reſiſt all Poyſon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Can men take comfort in the midſt of flames?
Bathe thy own body in a Cauldron of
Boyling Oyl, and then preach comfort! Swallow
Molten Lead, and tell me then of comfort!
My torment's much more exquiſite.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Alas, poor Gentleman! it grieves my heart
To ſee him thus.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who's he that grieves? Oh let me hug him I
My very Embrace will ſtraight dry up his Tears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Is there no cure?

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.l: I fear there's none: The Poyſon is ſo deadly,
It hath already ſeiz'd his Vital parts.
Cannot you gueſs who did adminiſter it?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not with much certainty: on the receipt
Of that ſame Paper his diſeaſe began.

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.l: Might it not be procur'd to make eſſay
If it were Poyſon'd?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It came from the Princeſs; he'll not part with't;
He ſtorms and rages if we but ſuſpect it:
How ſtill he is! he ſleeps ſure.

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.p: I fear his laſt: mark, but how pale he looks!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He's gone indeed! Farewel, thou Noble Soul!
Thou Mars of Arms! Belov'd in War and Peace!
'Mongſt all Deaths Triumphs he ſhall never boaſt,
T' have grac'd Elyzium with a Nobler Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.p: 'Twere fit enquiry were made about the Murther.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis very fit; and that we ſhould ſecure
That Fellow who brought the Letter.

sp.speaker: Phyſitian.
sp.l: Upon a Dog I'll the experience make
Whether it be poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Doctor, have a care, and fold it up
At diſtance from your Noſe: for that ſame Villain—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I fear you not: I have a Motto above your pow'r, Innocence is my Defence.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And may that clear you: I ſeek not Blood, But Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Unleſs he light upon the Name, I'm ſafe;
For that is onely poyſon'd: I hope
Valerio hath lickt the Venome off.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Captain, to your care I do commit
Maligno: ſee him ſafe, as you'll anſwer't.
Next, let's convey the Body in; where, in
Martial Accourtrements, let it be expos'd
To Publick View, till every Souldier
Hath dropt a tear: then it ſhall be interr'd
With all the great Solemnity of War:
In which, whilſt living, he took ſuch delight,
'Tis juſt, that dead, he have a Souldiers right.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Prince in Magical Robes, Luſſurio in Armour, Terraefilius, King, Guards, Juliana, Clariana.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: YOu know your Queſtion; and being examin'd,
The Anſwer you muſt make.

sp.speaker: Luf.
sp.p: In all I'm perfect.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Withdraw then; I hear him coming.
Your Lordſhip is moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: My curioſity was ſuch, I could not miſs my time.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Y'are indeed ſomewhat before your hour,
But not before I am prepar'd to ſerve you.
Twelve tedious hours are already ſpent
In Exorciſms, and inchanting Charms:
My Robes I've thrice with Ceremony chang'd;
Every Circle of deep Magick trac'd:
I've div'd in Horours as profound as Hell;
Summon'd to Council the Infernal Furies;
Seen Myſteries this Night would ſhake and chill
The blood of any common man to Ice,
And all to ſerve my Lord!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: But, my beſt Genius, canſt thou perform?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Elſe I ſhould curſe my ſtudies, and deſpiſe
My Art. In this Circle, my Lord, ſtand you
Secure, and neither move nor ſpeak to what
You ſee: for then you'll break my Covenant
With Hell, and ten thouſand Furies with horrour
Will upon you ſeize, and coſs your Carcaſe
Upon the boſome of a Northern ſtorm,
There to be ground to Atomes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I ſhall be circumſpect.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Obſerve your ſtation then.

lg.l: By Acheron, the River Styx,

l.hi: And all the ſpace that is betwixt
That and the bot Infernal Lake,

lg.l: Where Cerberus his Sop doth take;
Infernal Pluto keeps his Court,
And with fair Proſerpine doth ſport;
I do conjure fierce Radamant,
Aecus, Minos, Hell's Purſuvant,

l.hi: The compaſs of the earth to trace,
And bring the Prince unto this place
Within the twinkling of an eye.

sp.stage: A Man riſes like a Spirit.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: His Vertue bars that liberty:
But if that thou no more wilt claim,
Then Hell promiſe'd: in Pluto's Name
It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: His ſhadow you'll afford?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: You know the Devil never broke his word.
I'll ſend his ſhadow ſtraight: waft thrice your Wand,
And what you wiſh ſhall be at your command.
sp.stage: The Spirit deſcends. Enter Luſſurio in Armour.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: A pretty Incantation, and in Verſe:
If Ryme will do't, I'll ſee if I can pierce
This Aiery Prince: it looks as if 'twere he:
I'm ſure that I ſhould know that Armory.
Could I but hit him right! What, are you down?
Can Devils die? are Spirits mortal grown?
sp.stage: He kills Luſſurio. The Prince throws off his Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No: there's one ſtill lives to be reveng'd on thee.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: The Prince! Who is it then I have ſlain?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Luſſurio his ſhadow; for which I'll be reveng'd.
Will it not enter?
sp.stage: He makes a Paſs at Terraefilius.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thanks to my Privy Coat.
Are you ſo ſubtle, Prince? I'll try what
Proof you are.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Treaſon! Murther! Treaſon! Oh I am ſlain! On thee, bafe Slave, my blood will ſtill remain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Our Guard, what Outcry's this of Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: 'Tis met, Sir, and deſtroy'd. Finding the Prince.
Clad in this Mooriſh Garb for ſome deſigne
Upon your ſacred Life, I interpos'd
Between his fury and your danger, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Dear Father, hear me; and next lend belief
Unto my dying words: There's not a ſmile
Within that Fellows face, which is not Traytor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Merciful Gods, ſear up my Aged Ears;
Put double Cataracts upon my Eyes,
That I may neither hear nor ſee a ſon
So treacherous.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I hope your Majeſty 'll forgive my crime:
When your Life's in Queſtion, I am not my ſelf.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You merit rather a Reward:
That Traytor will finde his in Hell.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: That Villain cannot glory in my death;
His wounds were ſlight, your words rip up my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: See him ſecured, and ſafe kept: Caliſte,
I do commit him to thy cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: A Grave muſt ſhortly, Sir, my Priſon be,
When Death ſhall purchaſe my ſouls liberty.
But y'are too cruel to perplex me now,
Since all to dying men do peace allow.
sp.stage: Juliana and Clariana at the door.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: You muſt not enter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Muſt not! ſhall Clariana hear her Prince
Is ſlain, and ſtand diſputing?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What noiſe is that without?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: The Princeſs and the Dukes Daughter would have admittance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Let them enter.
sp.stage: They enter: Clariana runs to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh let me tear my fleſh to bind thoſe wounds!
Madam, the Prince is ſlain! Where's his Murtherer,
That I may ſhoot my eyes into his ſoul,
Like burning Beacons to torment it more,
Then if it were in Hell, and circled in
With Sulphur-flames might equalize his ſin?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Weep not, Juliana, for a man ſo worthleſs;
I' th' King my Fathers thoughts not worth a Tear.
Obedience ſhould teach thee to rejoyce,
Since the Kings peace is purchas'd by my blood:
Though blood of Peace an ill foundation be,
May his Peace ſpring from his ſons Tragedy.
Clariana, I muſt breathe on thee a Parting
Kiſs: Poor weeping Maid, too much beloved,
Too much unfortunate in being loved
By one that could not ſolemnize thy Rites.
Mayſt thou live happy in a ſecond choice!
Whilſt to my ſilent Grave I bear my love
And injuries. Commend me to the Duke:
Tell him, I grieve to leave on earth ſuch an
Angel-ſoul; mine can no longer bide here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Look to the Lady there; ſhe ſwoons: Daughter,
Methinks your love to us ſhould rather teach you
To congratulate our ſafety, then waſh
A Traytors Herſe with Tears.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He was my Brother, Sir; and Nature muſt
Reſent ſo near a loſs.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You had beſt take order for his Obſequies,
Leſt that the Rhetorick of theſe Ladies tears
Excite compaſſion in the Multitude.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You of the Guard, convey the Body hence,
Whilſt we withdraw to conſult publick ſafety.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Carry him where you pleaſe, I'll follow to His Grave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But firſt, 'twere fit we ſtudy on revenge:
Live but to finiſh that, we'll both prefer
Much before Life a Noble Sepulchre.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tho' he be dead, his Treaſons ſtill ſurvive;
His Troops in being, and the Duke alive.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thoſe threaten little now the Prince is gone;
He was the Pillar they depended on:
Proclaim your pardon, and they ſoon will yeild;
Yet ſome blood for example muſt be ſpill'd.
Exceſs of mercy makes all Traytors bold:
Had Gods no Juſtice, Vertue would be cold.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We'll both employ: Our ſevere Juſtice ſhall
Upon the Duke and chief Commanders fall,
Whilſt extended mercy doth forgive
All ignorant crimes, and let the Army live.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Mercy ſo us'd, doth no repentance breed;
For you deſtroy Rebellion in the ſeed.

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.l: 'TIs ſtrange we hear not of the Prince; he has
I'm confid •• t receiv'd advice both of
Valerio's Death, and my approach to Naples.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: But, what's more wonderful, your Meſſenger Returns not!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That doth diſtract me too: Me thinks he ſhould
With ſome Advices re-diſpatch him back.
We all are in a miſt; and our deſigne
(For want of proſecution) muſt needs give
Advantage to the Enemy: for ſoon
As Hortenſio hath notice of our March,
He'll rally up his forces, and purſue us.
From the Kings fury no leſs danger waits
On our March forward. Ruine will hem us in,
And pale Deſtruction like a hungry Grave,
Devour our Lives and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Our caſe is hard indeed, to forſake hopes
Of ſafety for a certain ruine.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Nay, certain ſafety: the reſolution
Was too promptly made, and too ſoon executed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You judge by the event: howe'er 't ſucceed,
The ſtratagem was high, and the deſigne.
Through-laid. We are not Gods, to mold our fate,
Or to foreſee futurity of chance:
We but propoſe; 'tis they diſpoſe of things;
They mold the Fortunes of the mightieſt Kings.
What means that ſhout?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: It ſpeaks the return, Sir, of your Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are moſt welcome, becauſe long expected.
Where are the Prince's Letters? 'Tis more then time
We knew his minde.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: The Prince? Alas!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why doſt thou ſtop, and wear upon thy looks
Diſtractions Livery?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Could you but read the Tragedy within,
You'd leave amazement, and tranſported be
To ſuch a highth of wonder, 'twould change you
To a Statue; or like weeping Niobe,
From a Fountain-top force you to diſtil
A Sea of blood for tears.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: For what moſt dire and fatal accident
Doſt thou prepare our ears? Is the Prince
Diſcovered, and in hold?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: In hold indeed: he's Priſoner to Death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: To Death!
Curſt be the tongue which gave that language voice,
Curſt be the ears that did receive the ſound,
And doubly curſt that guilty hand which durſt
Commit ſo vile a Regicide.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Ceaſe, good my Lord, to be ſo far enrag'd;
Let us revenge before we grieve his death:
In his juſt Quarrel we'll all ſpend our breath.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Noble Lieutenant, thy advice doth adde
New vigour to my ſoul: My curſes now
Shall change into revenge. The Gods knew well
How ſweet that power was, therefore reſerv'd
It wholly to themſelves; yet daring men
(By petty paſſions mov'd) do often try
To rob the Gods of that felicity:
With how much juſtice may I then revenge
The Prince his Murther on that damned Slave,
Who durſt in him give Vertue's ſelf a Grave!

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: To ſet a ſharper edge upon your ſwords,
Know, that his Murtherer is high infavour
With the King, and that it is reported
The Princeſs marriage muſt reward the act,
With whom he is to raign (th' old King being dead)
A Monarch here in Naples.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A King in Hell amongſt the Purple flames!
He ſhall be rewarded: Phalaris Bull,
Or ſome more horrid Inſtrument of death,
Which may with lingring, yet exceſſive pain,
Drink by degrees his life, and force him curſe
His ſoul to Hell for eaſe, ſhall be his recompence.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.p: But all this while his Name's to us unknown.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let it be Murtherer, or what it may,
My high revenge is levell'd at his ſoul.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: They call him Caliſto; but neither know
From whence, nor what he is.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But I know where to ſend him. This Caliſte
Muſt certainly be Terraefilius:
That Slave ſtill wore a murthering heart beneath
A ſmiling face. But come, let's haſte to Court:
If Blood be paſtime there, I'll make them ſport.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: THy grief to mine compar'd, is of ſo mean
A price, it looſeth all account.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I've loſt my Heart, my Lover, and my Prince.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And I my Love, Heart, Prince, and Brother too.
My dear Valerio's poyſon'd, yet I live.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amintor murther'd, and I onely grieve.

l.hi: My Love is dead, and my Heart is gone;
And yet I live,
And yet I grieve;

sp.l: But Frangypane will return anon

l.hi: From yonder cloud.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What a medley of ſorrow's here?

l.hi: He'll rip his ſhrowd,
And viſit me again:
But I'll no longer be
Guilty of cruelty,
By which he once was ſlain.
If that you ſpy
An Arrow fly,
And wound his Noble Heart,
Oh do not cry,
Oh do not ſtart,
'Tis but a glance
Of this bright eye
That doth advance
To viſit his poor Heart.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Poor innocent Maid! with what diſtracted,
Yet paſſionate Notes ſhe vents her griefs!
Were I diſtracted too, I might as ſhe
Perhaps in Songs vent all my miſery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That wiſh would but our miſeries augment:
For it would render us uncapable
To revenge the deaths of thoſe we grieve for.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know 'tis ignoble: but where there is
A want of ſtrength to bear a miſery,
To Nature ſure it is a charity
To wiſh our ſelves leſs ſenſible of grief.
I could afford to melt my ſoul in tears,
Diſtil my eyes like Marble in a ſweat,
If 'twould renew my dear Amintor's life:
But ſuch my mis'ry is, the more I grieve,
I've greater cauſe to grieve: Like damned fouls,
That ſuffer'd flames a hundred thouſand years,
Perceive their ſufferings of as great a length
When that time's finiſht, as when firſt begun:
So will the Prince his death appear to me,
And every day augment my miſery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Dry up thoſe liquid ſorrows: Joyn with me
In a Revenge may juſtifie your love,
And ſet his bones at reſt: Then we'll reſolve
Like Roman Dames to meet our Loves in ſhades,
Which neither jealouſie nor fate invades.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Womans ſtrength will fail in the attempt:
'Tis eaſier far for me to die my ſelf,
Then own the cruelty to deſtroy another.
Yet Death, though gildedne'en ſo well, is ſtill
Reliſht by Nature as a bitter Pill.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tho' Nature's weak, our loves may well ſupply
That poor defect, and teach us how to die;
And our Revenge ſo great a Juſtice is,
Nor gods nor men can ſay we do amiſs.
He'll ſtraight be here: come, come, you muſt reſolve:
Here, take this Ponyard: how you tremble at it!
Me thinks my Brothers death might fortifie
Your Arm.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That fatal word addes Courage.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why bravely ſaid! Think who you do revenge;
Think how he lov'd, how innocent he died,
Then ſtrike: Thou canſt not miſs the Traytors heart.
I'll grave as many wounds upon his fleſh,
As his vile murther made upon my heart;
And then the World and I may freely part.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I'll endeavour to follow your example:
So brave a Leader may well guide my hand
To all thoſe Actions which my fears withſtand:
But if my love I to your Precepts Joyn,
No Womans Courage ought to equal mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How well that ſpeech becomes my Clariana!
But ſince our Courage hath attain'd this heighth,
We muſt deviſe the apteſt means to perfect
Our Revenge.
Perſwade thou Livia bind him to this chair;
Her known madneſs will make't appear a Jeſt,
Should he diſcover it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But how to work her to it? Diſtracted Lovers
Are ſtill obſtinate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou ſay'ſt true; 'twill be ſomewhat difficult:
My griefs have made me looſe my brains.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What if we ſhould perſwade her that he did
Contrive the death of Frangypane?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twill be excellent. Dear Clariana,
Thou'rt for th' inventive, I the active part;
Sure both together cannot miſs his heart.
But ſilence now muſt make our counſels wiſe:
For ſee where comes the deſign'd ſacrifice!

div.head: Scoena Sexta.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: THe Prince his death was a ſucceſs beyond
All vulgar careſſes of fate: I nickt
The wheel of fortune when I ſtruck that ſtroke;
For his Diſguiſe did undermine my Plots.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Surely he ſees us not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Good Madam, let's obſerve.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Poor ſhallow Prince! did'ſt think to cope with me,
Whom ragged fortunes had made politick,
And opportunity a Knave? I muſt
Confeſs thy counterplots were dangerous
To my fate: Had fortune meant me but half
A courteſie, that ſtratagem might have
Swallow'd me and my deſignes in the
Deep gulph of ruine. But thanks my better ſtars,
My ſafety triumphs in thy death, which feeds
My ambition almoſt with certainty
Of that moſt glorious Prize ſhe aim'd at,
This Kingdome, and the Princeſs Love: ſtay there.
But what aſſurance have I of her love?
The Prince his word! A poor ſecurity!
A Reed I dare not reſt on. This Letter
Writ from the King t' endear me to her thoughts,
Is a foundation cannot fail my hopes:
Men born to Greatneſs, are but born to fall,
When brave ambition means to catch at all.
I'll boldly make a tender of my love;
And if refus'd, wed my revenge. — She turns!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: She's rarely wrought! you know your Qu.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Madam!
My laſt Addreſſes from your ſmiles receiv'd
So kinde a welcome, my heart dares not now
Doubt your love, ſince I bring th' Authority
Both of a Fathers and a Monarchs hand
To plead my intereſt, and implore your free
Conſent to conſummate my Vows.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, repoſe your ſelf, whilſt I have read
The Injunction of a Parent: you ſhall finde
Me rational in my reply.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She's kind beyond my hopes. Bleſt Terraefilius!
The Prince his Policy hath deceiv'd himſelf,
Since from the Princeſs he hath all conceal'd:
On ſome deſigne his death cut off i' th' middle.
As I live ſhe ſmiles; ſure the contents do pleaſe.
sp.stage: As be diſcourſes to himſelf, Livia binds him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Pretty Innocence! Your Woman, Madam,
Hath bound me to my good behaviour.

div.stage: Juliana and Clariana preſent ponyards to his breſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This ſhall ſet you free: ſtruggle not, nor uſe
Your voice: If you employ either, by my Brothers
Soul, I'll ſend yours to Hell immediately,
With all your fins upon you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Dear Princeſs, your hand implies an action,
Your heart I hope's too ſoft to execute.
If't be a tryal of my love you'd make,
Give me the Ponyard, and on your command
I'll rip my heart to let you ſee its truth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your love, baſe Slave, I ſcorn: 'Tis my revenge
(And for a Brothers death) I proſecute.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Hold! and do not on my innocence revenge
A crime I'm guiltleſs of.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou guiltleſs!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thou innocent!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: In thought as you: I knew him not when my
Unlucky and too fatal hand cut off
His blooming Youth. And might not this ſtrong Arm
Be uſeful to the King, Madam, to you,
And to th' Kingdomes ſafety, I'd cut it off:
So much I loath to think on the miſtake!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Vile Hypocrite, we from the Prince his mouth
Do too much know ere to believe thy lyes:
Ask briefly pardon of the Gods: We would
Not kill thy ſoul eternally.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yet unprepar'd he ſent the Prince to give
His laſt account.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He did, Clariana! This vile Traytor did it.
I joy to ſee thy ſpirit: but his ſoul
Was ſtill ſo innocent, and held ſo ſmall
Commerce with ſin, we need not doubt his ſafety.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I look upon the malice that was high,
And gave no leiſure for a penitent
Thought. Let's ſtrike!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How nobly ſhews this Courage!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Love and Revenge do fortifie my Arm,
And from a tim'rous Virgin me transform
To a bold, yet juſt puniſher of blood.
The Prince his blood in this ſame fellows guilt,
Appears as freſh as if 'twere newly built.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He weeps: how much he labours to ſeem good▪

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But tears are no ſufficient waſh for blood.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Had not thy words call'd from her drowſie Den
My juſt revenge, it had been drown'd in pity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Looſe not that ſpirit, Madam, you have put
In me; that noble ſpirit now rebukes
Your too much Lenity. If a Brothers
Death be no ugly fuel for the fire
Of your Revenge to feed on, Valerio's
Will fan it to a flame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How was my memory employ'd, that ſhe
Forgot that Noble ſoul! Could Pity take
Up all the Lodgings of my thoughts? Vile Maid,
Where was thy love? and where was thy revenge?
Both in his ſilent Grave.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How they inflame each other to deſtroy me!
Guilt makes me dull, and Danger ſtupid,
Elſe I might mix ſome eloquence with tears
To mollifie their hearts.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Is your peace made?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Oh ſtay!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I can defer no longer: Valerio's blood
Calls loud upon my ſoul for a revenge.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So doth the Prince's death: Come, let us ſtrike!
Both our concerns do ſpur us on alike.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Yet hold: tho' my innocence he a dumb
Advocate to your ears, yet let compaſſion
Mitigate your rage, or at leaſt give me time
To vindicate my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Madam, let's hear him out.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, Clariana, no; I'll be as deaf
As a Northern Wind the Mariners
Exclaims, to all he ſays. Were Angels ſent
To vindicate his innocence, I'd judge
Them Devils by their lyes: Let's not defer,
Leſt thou looſe courage too, and at one time
Our Womans ſtrength forſake us both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fear not: my ſoul doth want extention
To entertain my love and my revenge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You ſaw my Brother bleed, he bled by him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You heard Valerio di'd, he poiſon'd him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And on his heart I will revenge it thus.
Ha! will it not enter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Gods would have the Prince revenged firſt:
His Throat I hope's unarm'd.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That ſtroke was home indeed. Baſe Murthereſs,
I wiſh my blood were poiſon for thy ſake,
That every ſtain might make an ulc'rous ſore,
And by degrees conſume and rot your bones.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Baſe Slave, I'll ſtop your Throat.
Good Livia, ſtand aſide.
sp.stage: Whilſt ſhe ſpeaks to Livia, he catches her by the Gown.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Not yet; y'are within my graſp.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Nay, if y'are good at that, I'll ſtand at diſtance.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thy death ſhall ſet her free.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good Madam, one ſtroke for Frangypane.
I thank you heartily: 'twas a brave one!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My Death. Oh that my eyes had power to
Conſume you all! or that my dying breath
Might a contagion breed throughout the earth!
It grieves me not ſo much I am to fall,
Tho' from the pinacle of all my hopes,
As that my glories (by a female rage)
Are all eclips'd. Devil's revenge my death:
I can but curſe you, and ſo yeild my breath.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thy curſes will accompany thy ſoul.
Valerio, thou'rt reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The Prince may likewiſe reſt in Peace.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: And ſo may Frangypane.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Break ope the doors.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We are ſurpriz'd; but Death ſhall
Finiſh all. —

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why did you ſtrike before me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That I may carry tydings to the Prince.
That you will follow.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Commend my love likewiſe to Frangypane:
Tell him I'll grieve his death a ſcore of years,
And then I'll viſit him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They bounce again: diſpatch, dear Clariana.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas, my feeble arm its utmoſt courage ſhew'd,
In ſpilling boldly that baſe Traytors blood:
I dare not die.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Nor I, if I ſhould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then live here miſerably, whilſt I
Enjoy in the Elyzium ſhades my dear
Valerio's company. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, take me with you: for I feel deſires
Strong enough to lead me to the Prince.
My courage ebbs and flows juſt as my love,
And fears do dictate, but love triumphs now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: BE not ſo cruel to thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Y'are welcome; but too late.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I'll take your counſel, Sir: I can't abide
To have my love ſerv'd up in blood.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Give me thy hand;
I'll guide thee in this ſhady Pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Great Sir, you ſee the ſhipwracks you have made;
Your Sons innocence you already know;
Your Daughters you ne'er doubted, nor I mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I finde, and ſee too much.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My deareſt Clariana!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Grieve not for me: I finde a peace in death
Beyond all earthly comforts. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She's gone! for ever gone!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Adieu, dear Father. May your Throne be well
Secured by your Childrens blood! your Peace
Dayly by Subjects Loyalty encreaſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy wiſhes will be good for thoſe ſucceed
Me in this fatal Throne: My heart doth bleed
With ſuch an inward grief for my crimes paſt,
Caus'd by ſuſpition, and my needleſs fears,
By baſer Sycophants improv'd, I ſcarce
Can live to ask a Pardon, nor ſhe to give't.
That crack was timely: in the other world
I will implore 't of both.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Alas, poor King! grief crackt his aged heart.
My Lord, why do you waſte your tears in a
Single ſorrow, when a general grief
So much requires them?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What can be nearer then a Daughters death?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: A Soveraigns and the Peoples ſafety.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The King dead!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Heart-broke with grief.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then Nature muſt excuſe me: Grief, employ
Thy power to diſtil my ſoul in tears
Upon this Prince's Hearſe; whoſe much diſtruſt
Did heap on woes to haſten him to duſt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your ſorrow's comely: but the publick danger
(In my opinion) claims precedency.
Theſe dire events to Naples and her Crown,
Should they arrive unto the publick ear,
Ere you aſſert your right, or make your claim
(Which is undoubted) to this Realm, Faction
Might diſcompoſe the Publick Peace,
And ſo our griefs and dangers both increaſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Adviſe us, dear Hortenſio, now our friend:
Thy prompt complyance with us in revenge
Of Prince Amintors death, I never ſhall
Forget to own, or to neward.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The baſeneſs of the Murther did compel
That ſeeming Treachery: but my revole
You know was grounded upon honeſt thoughts,
And that we both meant ſafety to the King.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thou ſpeak'ſt an Angel-truth. — But to Our Right.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: We all ſalute you King.

sp.speaker: Capt. Sould.
sp.p: Long live Alphonſo, King of us and Naples.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We heartily your Acclamations greet.
Let all theſe Princely bodies be expos'd
To publick grief for a convenient time,
And then interr'd with high ſolemnity.
As for that Caitiff Slave, whoſe impious crimes
All Preſidents exceed; ſo let his Grave
Be in the bowels of devouring Wolves,
To whom let it be caſt a prey, whilſt we
Mutually grieve his great impiety.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: VVIT's grown ſo poor, thoſe Poets now excel
That in a Play expreſs but one thing well:
If new, 'tis ſuch a Miracle in Wit,
You ought admire, but not to cenſure it.
Yet Gallants, you do not conſider this,
But boldly cenſure every thing amiſs;
As if that Poets ought to have no fault,
When very Gods themſelves do ſometimes halt.
Troth you'd do well, before you cenſure it,
To try your ſelves if you can better it:
Which if y' effect, your Work much better ſhames
Thoſe you'd condemn, then now your loud exclaims.
But this our Author knew when firſt he writ,
He did create you Judges of his Wit,
Without diſputing of your learned skill;
His Doom's wholly depending on your Will.
Therefore proceed: whate'er your ſentence be,
'Twill but at worſt compleat his Tragedy.
But if in's favour you your Verdict give,
Loudly proclaim your Votes, and let it live.
